<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Arabs</h1>			<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
				<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>				<div id="contentSub"><span class="mw-redirectedfrom">  (Redirected from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arab&amp;redirect=no" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a>)</span></div>
				<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>				<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
				<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Arab" and "Arabian" redirect here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Arab_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Arab (disambiguation)">Arab (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabian_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Arabian (disambiguation)">Arabian (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"><caption class="fn org">Arabs</caption><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="nickname" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;font-size:115%;"><span lang="ar">عَرَب (<i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic language text">'arab</i>)</span></th></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;">Total population</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;450 million</span> (2011 est.)<sup id="cite_ref-Nydell_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nydell-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;">Regions with significant populations</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a><span class="nowrap">&#160;&#160;&#160;</span>430,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;"><i>Significant <a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">Arab diaspora</a> <br />(including partial ancestry)</i></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a></th><td>
12,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">&#91;a&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a></th><td>
6,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-variety.com_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety.com-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a></th><td>
5,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a></th><td>
5,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;b&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-iraqisinturkey_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iraqisinturkey-10">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-www.washingtoninstitute.org_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.washingtoninstitute.org-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-www.aljazeera.com_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.aljazeera.com-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNHCR-Turkey_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHCR-Turkey-13">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a></th><td>
3,500,000<sup id="cite_ref-The_Arab_American_Institute_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Arab_American_Institute-14">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a></th><td>
1,300,000–3,500,000<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> (native)</th><td>
1,700,000<sup id="cite_ref-arab-colpal_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arab-colpal-16">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;"><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a></th><td>

1,493,410<sup id="cite_ref-chad_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chad-20">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Mexico</th><td>
1,100,000<sup id="cite_ref-Ben_Cahoon_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ben_Cahoon-21">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Germany</th><td>
1,000,000+<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Chile</th><td>
700,000<sup id="cite_ref-aurora-israel.co.il_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aurora-israel.co.il-24">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Italy</th><td>
680,000<sup id="cite_ref-ISTAT_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISTAT-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">United Kingdom</th><td>
366,769<sup id="cite_ref-Naba11_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Naba11-26">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Canada</th><td>
380,620 (<a href="/wiki/Canada_2011_Census" class="mw-redirect" title="Canada 2011 Census">2011 Census</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Netherlands</th><td>
180,000<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Australia</th><td>
350,000<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Ecuador</th><td>
100,000–250,000<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" style="font-weight:normal;">Honduras</th><td>
150,000–200,000<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;">Languages</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;">Religion</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
<p>Predominantly: <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a><br />
(<a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufi</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Ibadi" title="Ibadi">Ibadi</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Alawite" class="mw-redirect" title="Alawite">Alawite</a>)<br />
Sizable minority: <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a><br />
(<a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Greek_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Catholic">Greek Catholic</a>)<br />
Smaller minority: Other monotheistic religions
(<a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>&#160;<b>&#183;</b>&#32;<a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá&#39;í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a>)<br />
</p>
Historically: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabian polytheism</a></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#b0c4de;">Related ethnic groups</th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
Other <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic-speaking peoples</a>, especially <a href="/wiki/Semitic_people" title="Semitic people">Semitic peoples</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a><sup id="cite_ref-evolutsioon_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-evolutsioon-32">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-sciencedaily_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencedaily-35">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-evolutsioon_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-evolutsioon-32">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Abraham_2010_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abraham_2010-36">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tadmouri2014-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;padding-top:0.5em;font-size:85%;text-align:left;">
<hr /><sup><small>a</small></sup> Arab ethnicity should not be confused with non-Arab ethnicities that are also native to the Arab world.<sup id="cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tadmouri2014-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><br /><sup><small>b</small></sup> Not all Arabs are Muslims and not all Muslims are Arabs. An Arab can follow any religion or irreligion.<br /><sup><small>c</small></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arab_identity" title="Arab identity">Arab identity</a> is defined independently of religious identity.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table role="presentation" class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg/40px-Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg.png" width="40" height="18" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg/60px-Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg/80px-Arabic_albayancalligraphy.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="343" data-file-height="151" /></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Arabic_script" title="Arabic script">Arabic text</a>.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Arabic" title="Help:Arabic">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a>.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Arabs</b> (<span class="nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ær/: &#39;arr&#39; in &#39;marry&#39;">ær</span><span title="/ə/: &#39;a&#39; in &#39;about&#39;">ə</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span></span>/</a></span></span>;<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">عَرَب</span>&#8206; <small><a href="/wiki/ISO_233" title="ISO 233">ISO 233</a></small> <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">‘arab</i>, <small>Arabic pronunciation</small> <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">[ˈʕarab]</a></span><small class="nowrap">&#160;(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap"><a href="/wiki/File:Arabspronouncedar.oog.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20" /></a>&#160;</span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b1/Arabspronouncedar.oog.ogg" class="internal" title="Arabspronouncedar.oog.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</small>) are a population inhabiting the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>. They primarily live in the <a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Arab_League" title="Member states of the Arab League">Arab states</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>, and western <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean_islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian Ocean islands">Indian Ocean islands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-40">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> They also form a significant <a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">diaspora</a>, with Arab communities established around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first mention of Arabs is from the mid-ninth century BCE as a tribal people in eastern and southern <a href="/wiki/Syria_(region)" title="Syria (region)">Syria</a>, and the north of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> The Arabs appear to have been under the <a href="/wiki/Vassal" title="Vassal">vassalage</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a> (911–612 BCE), and the succeeding <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian</a> (626–539 BCE), <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid</a> (539–332 BCE), <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian</a> empires.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">Arab tribes</a>, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a>, begin to appear in the southern <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Desert" title="Syrian Desert">Syrian Desert</a> from the mid 3rd century CE onward, during the mid to later stages of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian</a> empires.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> Tradition holds that Arabs descend from <a href="/wiki/Ishmael" title="Ishmael">Ishmael</a>, the son of <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EoR-Ishmael_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EoR-Ishmael-45">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a> is the birthplace of "Arab",<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> as well other Arab groups that spread in the land and existed for millennia.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a> (632–661), "Arab" referred to any of the largely <a href="/wiki/Nomadic" class="mw-redirect" title="Nomadic">nomadic</a> and settled <a href="/wiki/Semitic_people" title="Semitic people">Semitic people</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Desert" title="Syrian Desert">Syrian Desert</a>, North and Lower <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Today, "Arab" refers to a large number of people whose native regions form the Arab world due to the spread of Arabs and the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic language</a> throughout the region during the <a href="/wiki/Early_Muslim_conquests" title="Early Muslim conquests">early Muslim conquests</a> of the 7th and 8th centuries and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Arabisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabisation">Arabisation</a> of indigenous populations.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> The Arabs forged the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun</a> (632–661), <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> (661–750), <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> (750–1517) and the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid</a> (901–1071) caliphates, whose borders reached southern <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> in the west, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> in the east, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> in the north, and the <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a> in the south. This was one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">largest land empires in history</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> In the early 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">First World War</a> signalled the end of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>; which had ruled much of the Arab world since conquering the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluk Sultanate</a> in 1517.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> This resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Defeat_and_dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Defeat and dissolution of the Ottoman Empire">defeat and dissolution</a> of the empire and the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Partition of the Ottoman Empire">partition of its territories</a>, forming the modern Arab states.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> Following the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Alexandria_Protocol" title="Alexandria Protocol">Alexandria Protocol</a> in 1944, the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> was founded on 22 March 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-History_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-History-53">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_Arab_League" title="Charter of the Arab League">Charter of the Arab League</a> endorsed the principle of an <a href="/wiki/Pan-Arabism" title="Pan-Arabism">Arab homeland</a> whilst respecting the individual sovereignty of its member states.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, Arabs primarily inhabit the 22 Arab states within the Arab League: <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comoros" title="Comoros">Comoros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Djibouti" title="Djibouti">Djibouti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauritania" title="Mauritania">Mauritania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">Palestine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>. The Arab world stretches around 13 million km<sup>2</sup>, from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> in the west to the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> in the east, and from the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> in the southeast. Beyond the boundaries of the League of Arab States, Arabs can also be found in the global <a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">diaspora</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-40">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> The ties that bind Arabs are ethnic, <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">linguistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">cultural</a>, historical, <a href="/wiki/Arab_identity" title="Arab identity">identical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_nationalism" title="Arab nationalism">nationalist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_Arab_League" title="Geography of the Arab League">geographical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Arab_League" title="Politics of the Arab League">political</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> The Arabs have their own customs, language, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic architecture">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_dance" title="Arab dance">dance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture#Media" title="Arab culture">media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">cuisine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture#Dress" title="Arab culture">dress</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture#Society" title="Arab culture">society</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture#Sports" title="Arab culture">sports</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia">mythology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> The total number of Arabs are an estimated 450 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Nydell_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nydell-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Arabs are a diverse group in terms of religious affiliations and practices. In the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">pre-Islamic</a> era, most Arabs followed <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheistic</a> religions. Some tribes had adopted <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> or <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, and a few individuals, the <i><a href="/wiki/Hanif" title="Hanif">hanifs</a></i>, apparently observed <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Today, about 93% of Arabs are adherents of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> and there are sizable Christian minorities.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arab_Muslims" title="Arab Muslims">Arab Muslims</a> primarily belong to the <a href="/wiki/Sunni" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunni">Sunni</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiite" class="mw-redirect" title="Shiite">Shiite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ibadi" title="Ibadi">Ibadi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alawite" class="mw-redirect" title="Alawite">Alawite</a> denominations. <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christians</a> generally follow one of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christian Churches</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Orthodox">Greek Orthodox</a> or <a href="/wiki/Greek_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Catholic">Greek Catholic</a> churches.<sup id="cite_ref-PharesIntro_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PharesIntro-60">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> Other smaller <a href="/wiki/Minority_religion" title="Minority religion">minority religions</a> are also followed, such as the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá&#39;í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a> and <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>.
</p><p>Arabs have greatly influenced and contributed to diverse fields, notably the arts and architecture, <a href="/wiki/Influence_of_Arabic_on_other_languages" title="Influence of Arabic on other languages">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic philosophy">philosophy</a>, mythology, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_ethics" title="Islamic ethics">ethics</a>, literature, politics, business, music, dance, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cinema" title="Arab cinema">cinema</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_medicine" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_science" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic science">science</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_inventions_in_the_medieval_Islamic_world" title="List of inventions in the medieval Islamic world">technology</a><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> in the ancient and modern history. Arab people are generally known for their <a href="/wiki/Generosity" title="Generosity">generosity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hospitality" title="Hospitality">hospitality</a><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> as well as their <a href="/wiki/Belief" title="Belief">beliefs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Family_values" title="Family values">family values</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Arab_(etymology)" title="Arab (etymology)">Arab (etymology)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg/220px-Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg" width="220" height="78" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg/330px-Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg/440px-Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3680" data-file-height="1300" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Epitaph_Imru-l-Qays_Louvre_AO4083.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arabic epitaph of <a href="/wiki/Imru%27_al-Qais" title="Imru&#39; al-Qais">Imru' al-Qais</a>, son of 'Amr, king of all the Arabs", inscribed in <a href="/wiki/Nabataean_script" class="mw-redirect" title="Nabataean script">Nabataean script</a>. Basalt, dated in 7 Kislul, 223, viz. 7 December 328 CE. Found at <a href="/wiki/Namara_inscription" title="Namara inscription">Nemara</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Hauran" title="Hauran">Hauran</a> (<a href="/wiki/Southern_Syria" title="Southern Syria">Southern Syria</a>).</div></div></div>
<p>The earliest documented use of the word "Arab" to refer to a people appears in the <a href="/wiki/Kurkh_Monoliths" title="Kurkh Monoliths">Kurkh Monoliths</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Akkadian_language" title="Akkadian language">Akkadian language</a> record of the ninth century BCE <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_conquest_of_Aram" title="Assyrian conquest of Aram">Assyrian conquest of Aram</a>, which referred to <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouins</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> under <a href="/wiki/Gindibu" title="Gindibu">King Gindibu</a>, who fought as part of a coalition opposed to <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Retsop105_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Retsop105-64">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> Listed among the booty captured by the army of king <a href="/wiki/Shalmaneser_III" title="Shalmaneser III">Shalmaneser III</a> of <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyria</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Qarqar" title="Battle of Qarqar">Battle of Qarqar</a> are 1000 camels of "Gi-in-di-bu'u the ar-ba-a-a" or "[the man] Gindibu belonging to the <i>Arab</i> (<i>ar-ba-a-a</i> being an adjectival <a href="/wiki/Arabic_nouns_and_adjectives#Nisba" title="Arabic nouns and adjectives">nisba</a> of the noun <i>ʿarab</i><sup id="cite_ref-Retsop105_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Retsop105-64">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>). The related word <i>ʾaʿrāb</i> is still used to refer to Bedouins today, in contrast to <i>ʿarab</i> which refers to Arabs in general.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest surviving indication of an Arab national identity is an inscription made in an archaic form of Arabic in 328 using the <a href="/wiki/Nabataean_alphabet" title="Nabataean alphabet">Nabataean alphabet</a>, which refers to <a href="/wiki/Imru%27_al-Qays_ibn_%27Amr" title="Imru&#39; al-Qays ibn &#39;Amr">Imru' al-Qays ibn 'Amr</a> as "King of all the Arabs".<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> refers to the Arabs in the Sinai, southern Palestine, and the frankincense region (Southern Arabia). Other ancient Greek historians like <a href="/wiki/Agatharchides" title="Agatharchides">Agatharchides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diodorus_Siculus" title="Diodorus Siculus">Diodorus Siculus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a> mention Arabs living in Mesopotamia (along the Euphrates), in Egypt (the Sinai and the Red Sea), southern Jordan (the <a href="/wiki/Nabataeans" title="Nabataeans">Nabataeans</a>), the Syrian steppe and in eastern Arabia (the people of <a href="/wiki/Gerrha" title="Gerrha">Gerrha</a>). Inscriptions dating to the 6th century BCE in Yemen include the term "Arab".<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The most popular Arab account holds that the word "Arab" came from an <a href="/wiki/Eponym" title="Eponym">eponymous</a> father called <a href="/wiki/Ya%27rub" title="Ya&#39;rub">Ya'rub</a> who was supposedly the first to speak Arabic. <a href="/wiki/Abu_Muhammad_al-Hasan_al-Hamdani" title="Abu Muhammad al-Hasan al-Hamdani">Abu Muhammad al-Hasan al-Hamdani</a> had another view; he states that Arabs were called <i>Gharab</i> ("West") by <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamians</a> because Bedouins originally resided to the west of Mesopotamia; the term was then corrupted into "Arab".
</p><p>Yet another view is held by <a href="/wiki/Al-Masudi" title="Al-Masudi">al-Masudi</a> that the word "Arabs" was initially applied to the <a href="/wiki/Ishmaelites" title="Ishmaelites">Ishmaelites</a> of the "<a href="/wiki/Arabah" title="Arabah">Arabah</a>" valley. In Biblical etymology, "Arab" (in Hebrew <i>Arvi</i> ) comes both from the desert origin of the Bedouins it originally described (<i>Arava</i> means wilderness).
</p><p>The root <i>ʿ-r-b</i> has several additional meanings in Semitic languages—including "west/sunset," "desert," "mingle," "mixed," "merchant," and "raven"—and are "comprehensible" with all of these having varying degrees of relevance to the emergence of the name. It is also possible that some forms were <a href="/wiki/Metathesis_(linguistics)" title="Metathesis (linguistics)">metathetical</a> from <i lang="sem-Latn" title="Semitic languages transliteration">ʿ-B-R</i> "moving around" (Arabic <i lang="ar-Latn" title="DIN 31635 Arabic (Arabic language) transliteration">ʿ-B-R</i> "traverse"), and hence, it is alleged, "nomadic."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Arabs" title="History of the Arabs">History of the Arabs</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Antiquity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabia</a></div>

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:lavender; border-top: 1px solid #aaa; style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Sharifate_of_Mecca" title="Sharifate of Mecca">Sharifate of Mecca</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 968–1925</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Sulayhid_dynasty" title="Sulayhid dynasty">Sulayhids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1047–1138</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Uyunid_dynasty" title="Uyunid dynasty">Uyunids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1076–1253</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Zurayids" title="Zurayids">Zurayids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1083–1174</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Nabhani_dynasty" title="Nabhani dynasty">Nabhanids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1154–1624</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Mahdids" title="Mahdids">Mahdids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1159–1174</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Rasulid_dynasty" title="Rasulid dynasty">Rasulids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1229–1454</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Usfurids" title="Usfurids">Usfurids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1253–1320</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Jarwanid_dynasty" title="Jarwanid dynasty">Jarwanids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1305–1487</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Kathiri" title="Kathiri">Kathirids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1395–1967</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Tahirids_(Yemen)" title="Tahirids (Yemen)">Tahirids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1454–1526</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Jabrids" title="Jabrids">Jabrids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1463–1521</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Rassids#The_Qasimid_state" title="Rassids">Qasimids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1597–1872</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Yaruba_dynasty" title="Yaruba dynasty">Ya'arubids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1624–1742</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Upper_Yafa" title="Upper Yafa">Upper Yafa</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1800–1967</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Muscat_and_Oman" title="Muscat and Oman">Muscat and Oman</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1820–1970</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Rashidi_dynasty" title="Rashidi dynasty">Rashidids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1836–1921</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Zanzibar" title="Sultanate of Zanzibar">Sultanate of Zanzibar</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1856–1964</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Qu%27aiti" title="Qu&#39;aiti">Qu'aitids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1858–1967</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Beihan" title="Emirate of Beihan">Emirate of Beihan</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1903–1967</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Idrisid_Emirate_of_Asir" title="Idrisid Emirate of Asir">Idrisids</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1906–1934</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Mutawakkilite_Kingdom_of_Yemen" title="Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen">Mutawakkilite Kingdom</a></td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1926–1970</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:lavender; border-top: 1px solid #aaa; padding-left:0.5em;"><b>Current monarchies</b></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Alaouite_dynasty" title="Alaouite dynasty">Alaouites</a> (<a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1631–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Qasimi" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Qasimi">Al Qasimi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ras_al_Khaymah" class="mw-redirect" title="Ras al Khaymah">Ras al Khaymah</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1727–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Qasimi" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Qasimi">Al Qasimi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sharjah" title="Sharjah">Sharjah</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1727–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/House_of_Saud" title="House of Saud">Al Saud</a> (<a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1744–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Said" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Said">Al Said </a> (<a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1749–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/House_of_Sabah" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Sabah">Al Sabah</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1752–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Nahyan_family" title="Al Nahyan family">Al Nahyan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Abu_Dhabi" title="Emirate of Abu Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1761–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Nuaim" title="Al Nuaim">Al Nuaim</a> (<a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Ajman" title="Emirate of Ajman">Ajman </a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1810–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Umm_al-Quwain" class="mw-redirect" title="Umm al-Quwain">Al Mu'alla</a> (<a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Umm_al-Quwain" class="mw-redirect" title="Emirate of Umm al-Quwain">Umm al-Quwain</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1775–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Khalifa_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Khalifa family">Al Khalifa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1783–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Maktoum" title="Al Maktoum">Al Maktoum</a> (<a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Dubai" title="Emirate of Dubai">Dubai</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1833–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/House_of_Thani" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Thani">Al Thani</a> (<a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1868–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Al_Sharqi" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Sharqi">Al Sharqi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Fujairah" class="mw-redirect" title="Emirate of Fujairah">Fujairah</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1900–present</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Hashemites" title="Hashemites">Hashemites</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>)</td><td style="text-align:right;"> 1921–present</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;padding-top:0;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_the_Arab_League_member_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Template:History of the Arab League member states"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_the_Arab_League_member_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Template talk:History of the Arab League member states"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_the_Arab_League_member_states&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Pre-Islamic Arabia refers to the Arabian Peninsula prior to the rise of Islam in the 630s. The study of Pre-Islamic Arabia is important to&#160;<a href="/wiki/Islamic_studies" title="Islamic studies">Islamic studies</a> as it provides the context for the development of Islam. Some of the settled communities in the Arabian Peninsula developed into distinctive civilizations. Sources for these civilizations are not extensive, and are limited to archaeological evidence, accounts written outside of Arabia, and Arab oral traditions later recorded by Islamic scholars. Among the most prominent civilizations was <a href="/wiki/Dilmun" title="Dilmun">Dilmun</a>, which arose around the 4th millennium BCE and lasted to 538 BCE, and <a href="/wiki/Thamud" title="Thamud">Thamud</a>, which arose around the 1st millennium BCE and lasted to about 300 CE. Additionally, from the beginning of the first millennium BCE, <a href="/wiki/Southern_Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern Arabia">Southern Arabia</a> was the home to a number of kingdoms, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sabaean_kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Sabaean kingdom">Sabaean kingdom</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">سَـبَـأ</span>&#8206;, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">translit.</a>&#160;</small><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">Saba'</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran&#124;34&#124;15&#124;e=17&#124;s=ns_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|34|15|e=17|s=ns-70">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> possibly <a href="/wiki/Sheba" title="Sheba">Sheba</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-Sheba-01_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sheba-01-71">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> and the coastal areas of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Eastern Arabia</a> were controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sassanians" class="mw-redirect" title="Sassanians">Sassanians</a> from 300 BCE.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins_and_early_history">Origins and early history</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Origins and early history">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Semitic-speaking_peoples" title="Ancient Semitic-speaking peoples">Ancient Semitic-speaking peoples</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proto-Arabic" title="Proto-Arabic">Proto-Arabic</a></div>
<p>According to Arab-<a href="/wiki/Islamic%E2%80%93Jewish_relations" title="Islamic–Jewish relations">Islamic-Jewish traditions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ishmael" title="Ishmael">Ishmael</a> was father of the Arabs, to be the ancestor of the <a href="/wiki/Ishmaelites" title="Ishmaelites">Ishmaelites</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Qahtanites.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Qahtanites.png/170px-Qahtanites.png" width="170" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Qahtanites.png/255px-Qahtanites.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Qahtanites.png/340px-Qahtanites.png 2x" data-file-width="2377" data-file-height="2397" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Qahtanites.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traditional <a href="/wiki/Qahtanite" title="Qahtanite">Qahtanite</a> genealogy</div></div></div>
<p>The first written attestation of the ethnonym <i>Arab</i> occurs in an <a href="/wiki/Akkadian_language" title="Akkadian language">Assyrian</a> inscription of 853 BCE, where <a href="/wiki/Shalmaneser_III" title="Shalmaneser III">Shalmaneser III</a> lists a King <a href="/wiki/Gindibu" title="Gindibu">Gindibu</a> of <i>mâtu arbâi</i> (Arab land) as among the people he defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Qarqar" title="Battle of Qarqar">Battle of Qarqar</a>. Some of the names given in these texts are <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" class="mw-redirect" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>, while others are the first attestations of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_North_Arabian" title="Ancient North Arabian">Ancient North Arabian</a> dialects. In fact several different ethnonyms are found in Assyrian texts that are conventionally translated "Arab": <i>Arabi, Arubu, Aribi</i> and <i>Urbi</i>. Many of the <a href="/wiki/Qedarite" title="Qedarite">Qedarite</a> queens were also described as queens of the <i>aribi</i>. The <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a> occasionally refers to <i>Aravi</i> peoples (or variants thereof), translated as "Arab" or "Arabian." The scope of the term at that early stage is unclear, but it seems to have referred to various desert-dwelling Semitic tribes in the <a href="/wiki/Syrian_Desert" title="Syrian Desert">Syrian Desert</a> and Arabia.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Arab tribes came into conflict with the Assyrians during the reign of the Assyrian king <a href="/wiki/Ashurbanipal" title="Ashurbanipal">Ashurbanipal</a>, and he records military victories against the powerful <a href="/wiki/Qedar" class="mw-redirect" title="Qedar">Qedar</a> tribe among others.
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Old_Arabic" title="Old Arabic">Old Arabic</a>&#160;diverges from&#160;<a href="/wiki/Central_Semitic" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Semitic">Central Semitic</a>&#160;by the beginning of the 1st millennium BCE.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NabateensRoutes.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/NabateensRoutes.png/220px-NabateensRoutes.png" width="220" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/NabateensRoutes.png/330px-NabateensRoutes.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/NabateensRoutes.png/440px-NabateensRoutes.png 2x" data-file-width="837" data-file-height="814" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:NabateensRoutes.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Nabataean trade routes in <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">Pre-Islamic Arabia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Medieval Arab <a href="/wiki/Genealogist" class="mw-redirect" title="Genealogist">genealogists</a> divided Arabs into three groups:
</p>
<ol><li>"Ancient Arabs", tribes that had vanished or been destroyed, such as <a href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%80d" title="ʿĀd">ʿĀd</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thamud" title="Thamud">Thamud</a>, often mentioned in the <a href="/wiki/Qur%27an" class="mw-redirect" title="Qur&#39;an">Qur'an</a> as examples of God's power to vanquish those who fought his prophets.</li>
<li>"Pure Arabs" of <a href="/wiki/South_Arabia" title="South Arabia">South Arabia</a>, descending from <a href="/wiki/Qahtan" class="mw-redirect" title="Qahtan">Qahtan</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Qahtanite" title="Qahtanite">Qahtanites</a> (Qahtanis) are said to have migrated from the land of <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> following the destruction of the <a href="/wiki/Ma%27rib_Dam" class="mw-redirect" title="Ma&#39;rib Dam">Ma'rib Dam</a> (<i>sadd Ma'rib</i>).</li>
<li>The "Arabized Arabs" (<i>mustaʿribah</i>) of Central Arabia (<a href="/wiki/Najd" title="Najd">Najd</a>) and North Arabia, descending from <a href="/wiki/Ishmael" title="Ishmael">Ishmael</a> the elder son of <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a>, through <a href="/wiki/Adnan" title="Adnan">Adnan</a> (hence, <a href="/wiki/Adnanites" title="Adnanites">Adnanites</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Genesis" title="Book of Genesis">Book of Genesis</a> narrates that <a href="/wiki/God_in_Abrahamic_religions" title="God in Abrahamic religions">God</a> promised <a href="/wiki/Hagar" title="Hagar">Hagar</a> to beget from Ishmael twelve princes and turn him to a great nation.<sup>(<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0117.htm#20">Genesis 17:20</a>)</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Jubilees" title="Book of Jubilees">Book of Jubilees</a> claims that the sons of <a href="/wiki/Ishmael" title="Ishmael">Ishmael</a> intermingled with the 6 sons of <a href="/wiki/Keturah" title="Keturah">Keturah</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Abraham" title="Abraham">Abraham</a>, and their descendants were called Arabs and <a href="/wiki/Ishmaelites" title="Ishmaelites">Ishmaelites</a>:</li></ol>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303468">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>And Ishmael and his sons, and the sons of <a href="/wiki/Keturah" title="Keturah">Keturah</a> and their sons, went together and dwelt from <a href="/wiki/Desert_of_Paran" title="Desert of Paran">Paran</a> to the entering in of <a href="/wiki/Babylon" title="Babylon">Babylon</a> in all the land towards the East facing the desert. And these mingled with each other, and their name was called Arabs, and <a href="/wiki/Ishmaelites" title="Ishmaelites">Ishmaelites</a>.</p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite>Book of Jubilees 20:13</cite></div>
</blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png/220px-Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png" width="220" height="96" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png/330px-Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png/440px-Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png 2x" data-file-width="988" data-file-height="432" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Assyrian_horsemen_arabs.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrian</a> horsemen pursue defeated Arabs</div></div></div>
<p>Assyrian and Babylonian Royal Inscriptions and North Arabian inscriptions from 9th to 6th century BCE, mention the king of Qedar as king of the Arabs and King of the Ishmaelites.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup>
Of the names of the sons of Ishmael the names "Nabat, Kedar, Abdeel, Dumah, Massa, and Teman" were mentioned in the Assyrian Royal Inscriptions as tribes of the Ishmaelites. Jesur was mentioned in Greek inscriptions in the 1st century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TCCKhaldun.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/TCCKhaldun.jpg/170px-TCCKhaldun.jpg" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/TCCKhaldun.jpg/255px-TCCKhaldun.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/TCCKhaldun.jpg/340px-TCCKhaldun.jpg 2x" data-file-width="402" data-file-height="604" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:TCCKhaldun.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Life-size bronze bust sculpture of <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun" title="Ibn Khaldun">Ibn Khaldun</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun" title="Ibn Khaldun">Ibn Khaldun</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Muqaddima" class="mw-redirect" title="Muqaddima">Muqaddima</a></i> distinguishes between sedentary Arabian Muslims who used to be <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a>, and Bedouin nomadic Arabs of the desert. He used the term "formerly nomadic" Arabs and refers to sedentary Muslims by the region or city they lived in, as in <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Yemen" title="Demographics of Yemen">Yemenis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Levity_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levity-79">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> The Christians of Italy and the Crusaders preferred the term <a href="/wiki/Saracens" class="mw-redirect" title="Saracens">Saracens</a> for all the Arabs and Muslims of that time.<sup id="cite_ref-Lionheart_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lionheart-80">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> The Christians of <a href="/wiki/Iberia" class="mw-redirect" title="Iberia">Iberia</a> used the term <a href="/wiki/Moors" title="Moors">Moor</a> to describe all the Arabs and Muslims of that time.
</p><p>Muslims of <a href="/wiki/Medina" title="Medina">Medina</a> referred to the <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> tribes of the deserts as the A'raab, and considered themselves sedentary, but were aware of their close racial bonds. The term "A'raab" mirrors the term Assyrians used to describe the closely related nomads they defeated in Syria. The <a href="/wiki/Qur%27an" class="mw-redirect" title="Qur&#39;an">Qur'an</a> does not use the word <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʿarab</i>, only the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_nouns_and_adjectives#Nisba" title="Arabic nouns and adjectives">nisba</a> adjective <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʿarabiy</i>. The Qur'an calls itself <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʿarabiy</i>, "Arabic", and <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">Mubin</i>, "clear". The two qualities are connected for example in ayat <a href="/wiki/Az-Zukhruf" title="Az-Zukhruf">43</a>.2–3, "By the <i>clear</i> Book: We have made it an <i>Arabic</i> recitation in order that you may understand". The Qur'an became regarded as the prime example of the <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">al-ʿarabiyya</i>, the language of the Arabs. The term <i><a href="/wiki/%CA%BEi%CA%BFr%C4%81b" class="mw-redirect" title="ʾiʿrāb">ʾiʿrāb</a></i> has the same root and refers to a particularly clear and correct mode of speech. The plural noun <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʾaʿrāb</i> refers to the <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouin</a> tribes of the desert who resisted Muhammad, for example in <i><a href="/wiki/At-Tawba" title="At-Tawba">at-Tawba</a></i> 97,
</p><p><i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">al-ʾaʿrābu ʾašaddu kufrān wanifāqān</i> "the Bedouin are the worst in <a href="/wiki/Kufr" class="mw-redirect" title="Kufr">disbelief</a> and hypocrisy".
</p><p>Based on this, in early Islamic terminology, <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʿarabiy</i> referred to the language, and <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">ʾaʿrāb</i> to the Arab Bedouins, carrying a negative connotation due to the Qur'anic verdict just cited. But after the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_conquest" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic conquest">Islamic conquest</a> of the eighth century, the language of the nomadic Arabs became regarded as the most pure by the grammarians following <a href="/wiki/Abi_Ishaq" class="mw-redirect" title="Abi Ishaq">Abi Ishaq</a>, and the term <i lang="ar-Latn" title="Arabic-language transliteration">kalam al-ʿArab</i>, "language of the Arabs", denoted the uncontaminated language of the Bedouins.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_kingdoms">Classical kingdoms</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Classical kingdoms">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Palmyra" title="Palmyra">Palmyra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nabateans" class="mw-redirect" title="Nabateans">Nabateans</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Petra,_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg/220px-Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg" width="220" height="201" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg/330px-Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg/440px-Petra%2C_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3494" data-file-height="3197" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Petra,_Al-Khazneh_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Façade of <a href="/wiki/Al_Khazneh" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Khazneh">Al Khazneh</a> in <a href="/wiki/Petra" title="Petra">Petra</a>, Jordan, built by the <a href="/wiki/Nabateans" class="mw-redirect" title="Nabateans">Nabateans</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Proto-Arabic, or <a href="/wiki/Ancient_North_Arabian" title="Ancient North Arabian">Ancient North Arabian</a>, texts give a clearer picture of the Arabs' emergence. The earliest are written in variants of <a href="/wiki/Epigraph_(literature)" title="Epigraph (literature)">epigraphic</a> south Arabian <i><a href="/wiki/South_Arabian_alphabet" class="mw-redirect" title="South Arabian alphabet">musnad</a></i> script, including the 8th century BCE <a href="/wiki/Al-Hasa" title="Al-Hasa">Hasaean</a> inscriptions of eastern Saudi Arabia, the 6th century BCE <a href="/wiki/Lihyanite" class="mw-redirect" title="Lihyanite">Lihyanite</a> texts of southeastern Saudi Arabia and the <a href="/wiki/Thamudic" title="Thamudic">Thamudic</a> texts found throughout the Arabian Peninsula and <a href="/wiki/Sinai" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinai">Sinai</a> (not in reality connected with <a href="/wiki/Thamud" title="Thamud">Thamud</a>).
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nabataeans" title="Nabataeans">Nabataeans</a> were nomadic Arabs who moved into territory vacated by the <a href="/wiki/Edomites" class="mw-redirect" title="Edomites">Edomites</a>&#160;– Semites who settled the region centuries before them. Their early inscriptions were in <a href="/wiki/Aramaic" class="mw-redirect" title="Aramaic">Aramaic</a>, but gradually switched to Arabic, and since they had writing, it was they who made the first inscriptions in Arabic. The <a href="/wiki/Nabataean_alphabet" title="Nabataean alphabet">Nabataean alphabet</a> was adopted by Arabs to the south, and evolved into modern Arabic script around the 4th century. This is attested by <a href="/wiki/Safaitic" title="Safaitic">Safaitic</a> inscriptions (beginning in the 1st century BCE) and the many Arabic personal names in <a href="/wiki/Nabataean" class="mw-redirect" title="Nabataean">Nabataean</a> inscriptions. From about the 2nd century BCE, a few inscriptions from <a href="/wiki/Qaryat_al-Faw" title="Qaryat al-Faw">Qaryat al-Faw</a> reveal a dialect no longer considered <i>proto-Arabic</i>, but <i>pre-classical Arabic</i>. Five <a href="/wiki/Syriac_language" title="Syriac language">Syriac</a> inscriptions mentioning Arabs have been found at <a href="/wiki/Sumatar_Harabesi" title="Sumatar Harabesi">Sumatar Harabesi</a>, one of which dates to the 2nd century CE.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Temple_of_Bel,_Palmyra_15.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg/220px-Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg" width="220" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg/330px-Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg/440px-Temple_of_Bel%2C_Palmyra_15.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="1797" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Temple_of_Bel,_Palmyra_15.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The ruins of Palmyra. The Palmyrenes were a mix of Arabs, <a href="/wiki/Amorites" title="Amorites">Amorites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arameans" title="Arameans">Arameans</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Arabs arrived in the <a href="/wiki/Palmyra" title="Palmyra">Palmyra</a> in the late first millennium BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryce2014&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidXno9AgAAQBAJpgPA278_278&#93;_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryce2014[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidXno9AgAAQBAJpgPA278_278]-81">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> The soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/Sheikh" title="Sheikh">sheikh</a> Zabdibel, who aided the Seleucids in the battle of Raphia (217 BCE), were described as Arabs; Zabdibel and his men were not actually identified as Palmyrenes in the texts, but the name "Zabdibel" is a Palmyrene name leading to the conclusion that the sheikh hailed from Palmyra.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryce2014&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidXno9AgAAQBAJpgPA359_359&#93;_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryce2014[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidXno9AgAAQBAJpgPA359_359]-82">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> Palmyra was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a> after its 634 capture by the Arab general <a href="/wiki/Khalid_ibn_al-Walid" title="Khalid ibn al-Walid">Khalid ibn al-Walid</a>, who took the city on his way to Damascus; an 18-day march by his <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_army" title="Rashidun army">army</a> through the Syrian Desert from Mesopotamia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurns2007&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidpoCBAgAAQBAJpgPA99_99&#93;_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurns2007[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidpoCBAgAAQBAJpgPA99_99]-83">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> By then Palmyra was limited to the Diocletian camp.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpeake1996&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidR44VRnNCzAYCpgPA568_568&#93;_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpeake1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidR44VRnNCzAYCpgPA568_568]-84">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> After the conquest, the city became part of <a href="/wiki/Jund_Hims" title="Jund Hims">Homs Province</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELe_Strange189036_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELe_Strange189036-85">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg/170px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg" width="170" height="87" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg/255px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg/340px-Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2472" data-file-height="1260" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pergamon-Museum_-_Wandmalerei_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fragment of a wall painting showing a Kindite king, 1st century CE</div></div></div>
<p>Palmyra prospered as part of the Umayyad Caliphate, and its population grew.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHillenbrand1999&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQ6ppv17CP6ECpgPA87_87&#93;_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHillenbrand1999[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQ6ppv17CP6ECpgPA87_87]-86">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> It was a key stop on the East-West trade route, with a large <i><a href="/wiki/Souq" title="Souq">souq</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">سُـوق</span>&#8206;, <a href="/wiki/Marketplace" title="Marketplace">market</a>), built by the Umayyads,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHillenbrand1999&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQ6ppv17CP6ECpgPA87_87&#93;_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHillenbrand1999[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQ6ppv17CP6ECpgPA87_87]-86">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBacharach1996&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidNdCTI5FqayACpgPA31_31&#93;_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBacharach1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidNdCTI5FqayACpgPA31_31]-87">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> who also commissioned part of the Temple of Bel as a <a href="/wiki/Jama_Masjid" title="Jama Masjid">mosque</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBacharach1996&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidNdCTI5FqayACpgPA31_31&#93;_87-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBacharach1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidNdCTI5FqayACpgPA31_31]-87">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> During this period, Palmyra was a stronghold of the <a href="/wiki/Banu_Kalb" title="Banu Kalb">Banu Kalb</a> tribe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrabarHolodKnustadTrousdale1978&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQMSCNQlywSsCpgPA156_156&#93;_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrabarHolodKnustadTrousdale1978[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidQMSCNQlywSsCpgPA156_156]-88">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> After being defeated by <a href="/wiki/Marwan_II" title="Marwan II">Marwan II</a> during a <a href="/wiki/Third_Muslim_Civil_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Muslim Civil War">civil war in the caliphate</a>, Umayyad contender <a href="/wiki/Sulayman_ibn_Hisham" title="Sulayman ibn Hisham">Sulayman ibn Hisham</a> fled to the Banu Kalb in Palmyra, but eventually pledged allegiance to Marwan in 744; Palmyra continued to oppose Marwan until the surrender of the Banu Kalb leader al-Abrash al-Kalbi in 745.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawting1991&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidtPsUAAAAIAAJpgPA624_624&#93;_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawting1991[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidtPsUAAAAIAAJpgPA624_624]-89">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> That year, Marwan ordered the city's walls demolished.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpeake1996&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksidR44VRnNCzAYCpgPA568_568&#93;_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpeake1996[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidR44VRnNCzAYCpgPA568_568]-84">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECobb2001&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA73_73&#93;_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECobb2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA73_73]-90">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> In 750 a revolt, led by <a href="/wiki/Abu_al-Ward" title="Abu al-Ward">Majza'a ibn al-Kawthar</a> and Umayyad pretender <a href="/wiki/Abu_Muhammad_al-Sufyani" title="Abu Muhammad al-Sufyani">Abu Muhammad al-Sufyani</a>, against the new <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a> swept across Syria;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECobb2001&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA47_47&#93;_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECobb2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA47_47]-91">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> the tribes in Palmyra supported the rebels.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECobb2001&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA48_48&#93;_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECobb2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA48_48]-92">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> After his defeat Abu Muhammad took refuge in the city, which withstood an Abbasid assault long enough to allow him to escape.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECobb2001&#91;httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA48_48&#93;_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECobb2001[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid2C6KIBw4F9YCpgPA48_48]-92">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_kingdoms">Late kingdoms</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Late kingdoms">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kindites" class="mw-redirect" title="Kindites">Kindites</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NE_565ad.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/NE_565ad.jpg/220px-NE_565ad.jpg" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/NE_565ad.jpg/330px-NE_565ad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/NE_565ad.jpg/440px-NE_565ad.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1477" data-file-height="973" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:NE_565ad.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a> in 565, showing the Lakhmids and their neighbors</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kindites" class="mw-redirect" title="Kindites">Kindites</a> were the last major migration of pre-Islamic Arabs out of Yemen to the north. The Ghassanids increased the Semitic presence in the then Hellenized <a href="/wiki/Syria_(Byzantine_province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Syria (Byzantine province)">Syria</a>, the majority of Semites were Aramaic peoples. They mainly settled in the <a href="/wiki/Hauran" title="Hauran">Hauran</a> region and spread to modern <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, Palestine and East Jordan.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg/220px-Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg.png" width="220" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg/330px-Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg/440px-Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2186" data-file-height="1817" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Roman_Empire_125_political_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Imperial_province" title="Imperial province">imperial province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Arabia_Petraea" title="Arabia Petraea">Arabia Petraea</a> in 117–138 CE</div></div></div>
<p>Greeks and Romans referred to all the nomadic population of the desert in the Near East as Arabi. The Romans called Yemen "<a href="/wiki/Arabia_Felix" title="Arabia Felix">Arabia Felix</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> The Romans called the vassal nomadic states within the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Arabia_Petraea" title="Arabia Petraea">Arabia Petraea</a></i>, after the city of <a href="/wiki/Petra" title="Petra">Petra</a>, and called unconquered deserts bordering the empire to the south and east <a href="/wiki/Arabia_Magna" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia Magna">Arabia Magna</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a> as a dynasty inherited their power from the <a href="/wiki/Tanukh" class="mw-redirect" title="Tanukh">Tanukhids</a>, the mid Tigris region around their capital <a href="/wiki/Al-Hira" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Hira">Al-Hira</a>. They ended up allying with the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sassanids</a> against the Ghassanids and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>. The Lakhmids contested control of the Central Arabian tribes with the Kindites with the Lakhmids eventually destroying <a href="/wiki/Kindah" title="Kindah">Kinda</a> in 540 after the fall of their main ally <a href="/wiki/Himyar" class="mw-redirect" title="Himyar">Himyar</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persian</a> Sassanids dissolved the Lakhmid dynasty in 602, being under puppet kings, then under their direct control.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
The Kindites migrated from Yemen along with the Ghassanids and Lakhmids, but were turned back in Bahrain by the Abdul Qais <a href="/wiki/Rabi%60ah" title="Rabi`ah">Rabi'a</a> tribe. They returned to Yemen and allied themselves with the Himyarites who installed them as a vassal kingdom that ruled Central Arabia from "Qaryah Dhat Kahl" (the present-day called Qaryat al-Faw). They ruled much of the Northern/Central Arabian peninsula, until they were destroyed by the Lakhmid king <a href="/wiki/Al-Mundhir_III_ibn_al-Nu%27man" title="Al-Mundhir III ibn al-Nu&#39;man">Al-Mundhir</a>, and his son <a href="/wiki/%27Amr_III_ibn_al-Mundhir" title="&#39;Amr III ibn al-Mundhir">'Amr</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_period">Medieval period</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Medieval period">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Arab_conquests" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab conquests">Arab conquests</a></div>
