<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg/220px-Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg.png" width="220" height="101" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg/330px-Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg/440px-Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="413" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_expansion_of_Caliphate.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Age of the <a href="/wiki/Caliph" class="mw-redirect" title="Caliph">Caliphs</a> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #a1584e; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Expansion under <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>, 622–632/A.H. 1–11</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ef9070; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Expansion during the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Rashidun Empire">Rashidun Caliphate</a>, 632–661/A.H. 11–40</div> <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fad07d; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;Expansion during the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, 661–750/A.H. 40–129</div></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Arab_caliphates">Arab caliphates</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Arab caliphates">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<h5><span id="Rashidun_era_.28632.E2.80.93661.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Rashidun_era_(632–661)">Rashidun era (632–661)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Rashidun era (632–661)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a></div>
<p>After the death of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> in 632, <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_army" title="Rashidun army">Rashidun armies</a> launched campaigns of conquest, establishing the <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">Caliphate</a>, or Islamic Empire, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">largest empires in history</a>. It was larger and lasted longer than the previous Arab empire of <a href="/wiki/Mavia_(queen)" title="Mavia (queen)">Queen Mawia</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Arameans" title="Arameans">Aramean</a>-Arab <a href="/wiki/Palmyrene_Empire" title="Palmyrene Empire">Palmyrene Empire</a>. The Rashidun state was a completely new state and unlike the Arab kingdoms of its century such as the <a href="/wiki/Himyarite" class="mw-redirect" title="Himyarite">Himyarite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a> or <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a>.
</p>
<h5><span id="Umayyad_era_.28661.E2.80.93750_.26_756.E2.80.931031.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Umayyad_era_(661–750_&amp;_756–1031)">Umayyad era (661–750 &amp; 756–1031)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Umayyad era (661–750 &amp; 756–1031)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a></div><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Caliphate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Caliphate of Córdoba">Caliphate of Córdoba</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a></div><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Abbadid" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbadid">Abbadid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taifa" title="Taifa">Taifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nasrid_dynasty_(Sistan)" title="Nasrid dynasty (Sistan)">Nasrid dynasty (Sistan)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zengid_dynasty" title="Zengid dynasty">Zengid dynasty</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ikhshidid_dynasty" title="Ikhshidid dynasty">Ikhshidid dynasty</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg/220px-Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg/330px-Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg/440px-Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3280" data-file-height="2270" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan_Panorama_-_Grande_Mosqu%C3%A9e_de_Kairouan_Panorama.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Mosque_of_Kairouan" title="Great Mosque of Kairouan">Great Mosque of Kairouan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kairouan" title="Kairouan">Kairouan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> was founded in 670 by the Arab general <a href="/wiki/Uqba_ibn_Nafi" title="Uqba ibn Nafi">Uqba ibn Nafi</a>; it is the oldest mosque in the Maghreb<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> and represents an architectural testimony of the Arab conquest of <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg/220px-Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg" width="220" height="58" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg/330px-Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg/440px-Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg 2x" data-file-width="9924" data-file-height="2615" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Umayyad_Mosquee_panoramic.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Mosque" title="Umayyad Mosque">Umayyad Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>, built in 715, is one of the oldest, largest and best preserved <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">mosques</a> in the world</div></div></div>
<p>In 661, the Rashidun Caliphate fell into the hands of the <a href="/wiki/Banu_Umayya" title="Banu Umayya">Umayyad dynasty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a> was established as the empire's capital. The Umayyads were proud of their Arab identity and sponsored the poetry and culture of pre-Islamic Arabia. They established garrison towns at <a href="/wiki/Ramla" title="Ramla">Ramla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raqqa" title="Raqqa">Raqqa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basra" title="Basra">Basra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kufa" title="Kufa">Kufa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mosul" title="Mosul">Mosul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samarra" title="Samarra">Samarra</a>, all of which developed into major cities.<sup id="cite_ref-Lunde_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lunde-96">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Caliph" class="mw-redirect" title="Caliph">Caliph</a> <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Malik_ibn_Marwan" title="Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan">Abd al-Malik</a> established Arabic as the Caliphate's official language in 686.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup> This reform greatly influenced the conquered non-Arab peoples and fueled the <a href="/wiki/Arabization" title="Arabization">Arabization</a> of the region. However, the Arabs' higher status among non-Arab Muslim converts and the latter's obligation to pay heavy taxes caused resentment. Caliph <a href="/wiki/Umar_II" title="Umar II">Umar II</a> strove to resolve the conflict when he came to power in 717. He rectified the disparity, demanding that all Muslims be treated as equals, but his intended reforms did not take effect, as he died after only three years of rule. By now, discontent with the Umayyads swept the region and an uprising occurred in which the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasids</a> came to power and moved the capital to <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dome_of_the_Rock_III,_Jerusalem.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/220px-Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/330px-Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg/440px-Dome_of_the_Rock_III%2C_Jerusalem.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5128" data-file-height="3389" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dome_of_the_Rock_III,_Jerusalem.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, constructed during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Malik_ibn_Marwan" title="Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan">Abd al Malik</a></div></div></div>
<p>Umayyads expanded their Empire westwards capturing North Africa from the Byzantines. Before the Arab conquest, North Africa was conquered or settled by various people including <a href="/wiki/Punics" title="Punics">Punics</a>, Vandals and Romans. After the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Revolution" title="Abbasid Revolution">Abbasid Revolution</a>, the Umayyads lost most of their territories with the exception of Iberia. Their last holding became known as the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Emirate of Córdoba">Emirate of Córdoba</a>. It wasn't until the rule of the grandson of the founder of this new emirate that the state entered a new phase as the <a href="/wiki/Caliphate_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Caliphate of Córdoba">Caliphate of Córdoba</a>. This new state was characterized by an expansion of trade, culture and knowledge, and saw the construction of masterpieces of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a> architecture and the library of <a href="/wiki/Al-%E1%B8%A4akam_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Ḥakam II">Al-Ḥakam II</a> which housed over 400,000 volumes. With the collapse of the Umayyad state in 1031 CE, <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Islamic Spain</a> was divided into small kingdoms.
</p>
<h5><span id="Abbassid_era_.28750.E2.80.931258_.26_1261.E2.80.931517.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Abbassid_era_(750–1258_&amp;_1261–1517)">Abbassid era (750–1258 &amp; 1261–1517)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Abbassid era (750–1258 &amp; 1261–1517)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg/170px-Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg/255px-Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg/340px-Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1680" data-file-height="2240" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mustansiriya_University_CPT.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mustansiriya_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Mustansiriya University">Mustansiriya University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maqamat_hariri.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Maqamat_hariri.jpg/170px-Maqamat_hariri.jpg" width="170" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Maqamat_hariri.jpg/255px-Maqamat_hariri.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Maqamat_hariri.jpg/340px-Maqamat_hariri.jpg 2x" data-file-width="453" data-file-height="461" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Maqamat_hariri.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Scholars at an Abbasid library in Baghdad. Maqamat of al-Hariri Illustration, 123.</div></div></div>
<p>The Abbasids were&#160;the descendants of&#160;<a href="/wiki/Al-Abbas_ibn_Abd_al-Muttalib" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib">Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib</a>, one of the youngest uncles of Muhammad and of the same&#160;<a href="/wiki/Banu_Hashim" title="Banu Hashim">Banu Hashim</a>&#160;clan. The Abbasids led a revolt against the Umayyads and defeated them in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Zab" title="Battle of the Zab">Battle of the Zab</a> effectively ending their rule in all parts of the Empire with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a>. In 762, the second Abbasid Caliph <a href="/wiki/Al-Mansur" title="Al-Mansur">al-Mansur</a> founded the city of <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a> and declared it the capital of the Caliphate. Unlike the Umayyads, the Abbasids had the support of non-Arab subjects.<sup id="cite_ref-Lunde_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lunde-96">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a> was inaugurated by the middle of the 8th century by the ascension of the Abbasid Caliphate and the transfer of the capital from <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a> to the newly founded city of <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>. The Abbassids were influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Qur%27an" class="mw-redirect" title="Qur&#39;an">Qur'anic</a> injunctions and <a href="/wiki/Hadith" title="Hadith">hadith</a> such as "The ink of the scholar is more holy than the blood of martyrs" stressing the value of knowledge. During this period the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> became an intellectual centre for science, philosophy, medicine and education as the Abbasids championed the cause of knowledge and established the "<a href="/wiki/House_of_Wisdom" title="House of Wisdom">House of Wisdom</a>" (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">بيت الحكمة</span>&#8206;) in Baghdad. Rival dynasties such as the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid" class="mw-redirect" title="Fatimid">Fatimids</a> of <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad" class="mw-redirect" title="Umayyad">Umayyads</a> of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a> were also major intellectual centres with cities such as <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> and <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B3rdoba,_Spain" title="Córdoba, Spain">Córdoba</a> rivaling <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Vartan_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vartan-98">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Harun-Charlemagne.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Harun-Charlemagne.jpg/170px-Harun-Charlemagne.jpg" width="170" height="106" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Harun-Charlemagne.jpg/255px-Harun-Charlemagne.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Harun-Charlemagne.jpg/340px-Harun-Charlemagne.jpg 2x" data-file-width="765" data-file-height="477" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Harun-Charlemagne.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Harun_al-Rashid" title="Harun al-Rashid">Harun al-Rashid</a> receiving a delegation sent by <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Abbasids ruled for 200 years before they lost their central control when <a href="/wiki/Wilayah" title="Wilayah">Wilayas</a> began to fracture in the 10th century; afterwards, in the 1190s, there was a revival of their power, which was ended by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongols</a>, who <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Baghdad_(1258)" title="Siege of Baghdad (1258)">conquered Baghdad</a> in 1258 and killed the Caliph <a href="/wiki/Al-Musta%27sim" title="Al-Musta&#39;sim">Al-Musta'sim</a>. Members of the Abbasid royal family escaped the massacre and resorted to Cairo, which had broken from the Abbasid rule two years earlier; the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluk</a> generals taking the political side of the kingdom while Abbasid Caliphs were engaged in civil activities and continued patronizing science, arts and literature.
</p>
<h5><span id="Fatimid_Caliphate_.28909.E2.80.931171.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Fatimid_Caliphate_(909–1171)">Fatimid Caliphate (909–1171)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Fatimid Caliphate (909–1171)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid Caliphate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg/170px-A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg/255px-A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg/340px-A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg 2x" data-file-width="2825" data-file-height="4238" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:A_side_view_of_the_front_gate_of_Al_Azhar_mosque..jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Al-Azhar_Mosque" title="Al-Azhar Mosque">Al-Azhar Mosque</a>, commissioned by the Fatimid Caliph <a href="/wiki/Al-Mu%27izz_li-Din_Allah" title="Al-Mu&#39;izz li-Din Allah">Al-Mu'izz</a> for the newly established capital city of <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> in 969</div></div></div>
<p>The Fatimid caliphate was founded by <a href="/wiki/Abdullah_al-Mahdi_Billah" title="Abdullah al-Mahdi Billah">al-Mahdi Billah</a>, a descendant of <a href="/wiki/Fatimah" title="Fatimah">Fatimah</a>, the daughter of Muhammad, in the early 10th century. Egypt was the political, cultural, and religious centre of the Fatimid empire. The Fatimid state took shape among the <a href="/wiki/Kutama" title="Kutama">Kutama</a> Berbers, in the West of the North African littoral, in Algeria, in 909 conquering <a href="/wiki/Raqqada" title="Raqqada">Raqqada</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Aghlabid" class="mw-redirect" title="Aghlabid">Aghlabid</a> capital. In 921 the Fatimids established the Tunisian city of <a href="/wiki/Mahdia" title="Mahdia">Mahdia</a> as their new capital. In 948 they shifted their capital to <a href="/wiki/Al-Mansuriya" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Mansuriya">Al-Mansuriya</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Kairouan" title="Kairouan">Kairouan</a> in Tunisia, and in 969 they conquered Egypt and established <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> as the capital of their caliphate.
</p><p>Intellectual life in Egypt during the Fatimid period achieved great progress and activity, due to many scholars who lived in or came to Egypt, as well as the number of books available. Fatimid Caliphs gave prominent positions to scholars in their courts, encouraged students, and established libraries in their palaces, so that scholars might expand their knowledge and reap benefits from the work of their predecessors.<sup id="cite_ref-imamreza.net_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imamreza.net-99">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> The Fatimids were also known for their exquisite arts. Many traces of <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_architecture" title="Fatimid architecture">Fatimid architecture</a> exist in Cairo today; the most defining examples include <a href="/wiki/Al-Hakim_Mosque" title="Al-Hakim Mosque">Al-Hakim Mosque</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Al-Azhar_University" title="Al-Azhar University">Al-Azhar University</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg/220px-Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg" width="220" height="94" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg/330px-Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg/440px-Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="770" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Panel_hunters_Louvre_OA_6265-1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arabesque pattern behind hunters on <a href="/wiki/Ivory_carving" title="Ivory carving">ivory plaque</a>, 11th–12th century, Egypt</div></div></div>
<p>It was not until the 11th century that the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a> saw a large influx of ethnic Arabs. Starting with the 11th century, the Arab bedouin <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hilal" title="Banu Hilal">Banu Hilal</a> tribes migrated to the West. Having been sent by the <a href="/wiki/Fatimids" class="mw-redirect" title="Fatimids">Fatimids</a> to punish the Berber <a href="/wiki/Zirids" class="mw-redirect" title="Zirids">Zirids</a> for abandoning <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shias</a>, they travelled westwards. The Banu Hilal quickly defeated the Zirids and deeply weakened the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Hammadid" class="mw-redirect" title="Hammadid">Hammadids</a>. According to some modern historians. their influx was a major factor in the arabization of the Maghreb.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> Although Berbers ruled the region until the 16th century (under such powerful dynasties as the <a href="/wiki/Almoravids" class="mw-redirect" title="Almoravids">Almoravids</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Almohads" class="mw-redirect" title="Almohads">Almohads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hafsids" class="mw-redirect" title="Hafsids">Hafsids</a>, etc.), the arrival of these tribes eventually helped Arabize much of it ethnically, in addition to the linguistic and political impact on local non-Arabs.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire">Ottoman Empire</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Ottoman Empire">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">Ottoman Caliphate</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:030Arab.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/030Arab.jpg/220px-030Arab.jpg" width="220" height="129" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/030Arab.jpg/330px-030Arab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/030Arab.jpg/440px-030Arab.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="353" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:030Arab.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Soldiers of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Army" title="Arab Army">Arab Army</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Desert" title="Arabian Desert">Arabian Desert</a> carrying the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_Arab_Revolt" title="Flag of the Arab Revolt">Flag of the Arab Revolt</a></div></div></div>
<p>From 1517 to 1918, much of the Arab world was under the suzerainty of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The Ottomans defeated the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluk Sultanate</a> in Cairo, and ended the Abbasid Caliphate. Arabs did not feel the change of administration because the Ottomans modeled their rule after the previous Arab administration systems.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In 1911, Arab intellectuals and politicians from throughout the Levant formed <a href="/wiki/Al-Fatat" title="Al-Fatat">al-Fatat</a> ("the Young Arab Society"), a small Arab nationalist club, in Paris. Its stated aim was "raising the level of the Arab nation to the level of modern nations." In the first few years of its existence, al-Fatat called for greater autonomy within a unified Ottoman state rather than Arab independence from the empire. Al-Fatat hosted the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Congress_of_1913" title="Arab Congress of 1913">Arab Congress of 1913</a> in Paris, the purpose of which was to discuss desired reforms with other dissenting individuals from the Arab world. However, as the Ottoman authorities cracked down on the organization's activities and members, al-Fatat went underground and demanded the complete independence and unity of the Arab provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-Choueiri166_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Choueiri166-102">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, when the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, former Ottoman colonies were divided up between the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">French</a> as <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate" title="League of Nations mandate">League of Nations mandates</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_period">Modern period</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Modern period">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arab_World_maps.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Arab_World_maps.png/220px-Arab_World_maps.png" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d3/Arab_World_maps.png 1.5x" data-file-width="324" data-file-height="204" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arab_World_maps.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map of the Arab world</div></div></div>
<p>Arabs in modern times live in the Arab world, which comprises 22 countries in Western Asia, North Africa, and parts of the Horn of Africa. They are all modern states and became significant as distinct political entities after the fall and <a href="/wiki/Defeat_and_dissolution_of_the_Ottoman_Empire_(1908%E2%80%931922)" class="mw-redirect" title="Defeat and dissolution of the Ottoman Empire (1908–1922)">defeat and dissolution of the Ottoman Empire (1908–1922)</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Identity">Identity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Identity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Arab_identity" title="Arab identity">Arab identity</a></div>
<p>Arab identity is defined independently of <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religious</a> identity, and pre-dates the <a href="/wiki/Spread_of_Islam" title="Spread of Islam">spread of Islam</a>, with historically attested <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christian</a> kingdoms and <a href="/wiki/Jewish_tribes_of_Arabia" title="Jewish tribes of Arabia">Arab Jewish tribes</a>. Today, however, most Arabs are Muslim, with a minority adhering to other faiths, largely <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Middle_East" title="Christianity in the Middle East">Christianity</a>, but also <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá&#39;í Faith">Baha'i</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Paternal descent plays a strong part in the role of citizenship of an individual and maternal descent also plays an issue. Paternal descent is considered the main source of affiliation in the Arab world when it comes to membership into a kin group or clan.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> 
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:NE_565ad-Lakhmid.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/NE_565ad-Lakhmid.jpg/220px-NE_565ad-Lakhmid.jpg" width="220" height="144" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/NE_565ad-Lakhmid.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="329" data-file-height="215" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:NE_565ad-Lakhmid.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Near East in 565, showing the Ghassanids, Lakhmids, Kindah and <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a></div></div></div>
<p>Today, the main unifying characteristic among Arabs is <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Central_Semitic_languages" title="Central Semitic languages">Central Semitic language</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic language family</a>. <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Modern Standard Arabic</a> serves as the <a href="/wiki/Standard_language" title="Standard language">standardized</a> and <a href="/wiki/Literary_language" title="Literary language">literary</a> variety of Arabic used in writing. The Arabs are first mentioned in the mid-ninth century BCE as a tribal people dwelling in the central Arabian Peninsula subjugated by <a href="/wiki/Upper_Mesopotamia" title="Upper Mesopotamia">Upper Mesopotamia</a>-based state of Assyria. The Arabs appear to have remained largely under the vassalage of the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a> (911–605 BCE), and then the succeeding <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian Empire</a> (605–539 BCE), Persian <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> (539–332 BCE), <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Macedonians" title="Ancient Macedonians">Macedonian</a>/<a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a>.
</p><p>Arab tribes, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a> begin to appear in the south Syrian deserts and southern Jordan from the mid 3rd century CE onwards, during the mid to later stages of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>. Also, before them the <a href="/wiki/Nabataeans" title="Nabataeans">Nabataeans</a> of Jordan and arguably the <a href="/wiki/Royal_family_of_Emesa" title="Royal family of Emesa">Emessans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Osroene" title="Osroene">Edessans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hatra" title="Hatra">Hatrans</a><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> all appear to have been an Aramaic speaking ethnic Arabs who came to rule much of the pre-Islamic <a href="/wiki/Fertile_crescent" class="mw-redirect" title="Fertile crescent">fertile crescent</a> often as vassals of the two rival empires, the Sasanian (Persian) and the Byzantine (Eastern Roman).<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> Thus, although a more limited diffusion of Arab culture and language was felt in some areas by these migrant minority Arabs in <i>pre-Islamic</i> times through Arabic-speaking Christian kingdoms and Jewish tribes, it was only after the <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Rise of Islam">rise of Islam</a> in the mid-7th century that Arab culture, people and language began their wholesale spread from the central Arabian Peninsula (including the south Syrian desert) through conquest and trade.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Subgroups">Subgroups</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Subgroups">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">Tribes of Arabia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg/220px-Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg.png" width="220" height="180" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg/330px-Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg/440px-Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="860" data-file-height="702" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Arabia_600_AD.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Approximate locations of certain <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">tribes of Arabia</a>, including those descended from <a href="/wiki/Adnan" title="Adnan">Adnan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hawazin" title="Hawazin">Hawazin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Quraysh" title="Quraysh">Quraysh</a> at the dawn of Islam, 600 CE</div></div></div>
<p>Arabs in the narrow sense are the indigenous Arabians who trace their roots back to the <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">tribes of Arabia</a>. Within the people of the Arabian Peninsula, distinction is made between:
"Perishing Arabs" (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">الـعـرب الـبـائـدة</span>&#8206;) are ancient tribes of whose history little is known. They include <a href="/wiki/%CA%BF%C4%80d" title="ʿĀd">ʿĀd</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">عَـاد</span>&#8206;),<sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran&#124;54&#124;21&#124;e=26&#124;s=ns_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|54|21|e=26|s=ns-110">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Thamud" title="Thamud">Thamûd</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">ثَـمُـود</span>&#8206;,<sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran&#124;7&#124;73&#124;e=157&#124;s=ns_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|7|73|e=157|s=ns-111">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> Tasm, Jadis, Imlaq and others. Jadis and Tasm perished because of genocide. 'Aad and Thamud perished because of their decadence, as recorded in the Qur'an. Archaeologists have recently uncovered inscriptions that contain references to <i>Iram dhāṫ al-'Imād</i> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">إِرَم ذَات الـعِـمَـاد</span>&#8206;, <a href="/wiki/Iram_of_the_Pillars" title="Iram of the Pillars">Iram of the Pillars</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-Cite_quran&#124;54&#124;21&#124;e=26&#124;s=ns_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cite_quran|54|21|e=26|s=ns-110">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> which was a major city of the 'Aad. Imlaq is the singular form of 'Amaleeq and is probably synonymous to the biblical <a href="/wiki/Amalek" title="Amalek">Amalek</a>. "Pure Arabs" (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">الـعـرب الـعـاربـة</span>&#8206;) or <a href="/wiki/Qahtanites" class="mw-redirect" title="Qahtanites">Qahtanites</a> from <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>, taken to be descended from <a href="/wiki/Ya%27rub" title="Ya&#39;rub">Ya'rub ibn Yashjub ibn Qahtan</a> and further from <a href="/wiki/Hud_(prophet)" title="Hud (prophet)">Hud</a>. "Arabized Arabs" (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">الـعـرب الـمـسـتـعـربـة</span>&#8206;) or <a href="/wiki/Adnanites" title="Adnanites">Adnanites</a>, taken to be the descendants of <a href="/wiki/Ishmael" title="Ishmael">Ishmael</a> son of Abraham.
</p><p>
Arabians are most prevalent in the Arabian Peninsula, but are also found in large numbers in Mesopotamia (<a href="/wiki/Arab_tribes_in_Iraq" title="Arab tribes in Iraq">Arab tribes in Iraq</a>), the Levant and Sinai (<a href="/wiki/Negev_Bedouin" title="Negev Bedouin">Negev Bedouin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tarabin_bedouin" class="mw-redirect" title="Tarabin bedouin">Tarabin bedouin</a>), as well as the Maghreb (Eastern Libya, South Tunisia and South Algeria) and the Sudan region.</p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG/220px-Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG" width="220" height="195" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG/330px-Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG/440px-Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG 2x" data-file-width="1006" data-file-height="893" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pre_Islamic_Arabia.PNG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Arabian tribes before the spread of Islam</div></div></div>
<p>This traditional division of the Arabs of Arabia may have arisen at the time of the <a href="/wiki/First_Fitna" title="First Fitna">First Fitna</a>. Of the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_tribes_that_interacted_with_Muhammad" title="Arabian tribes that interacted with Muhammad">Arabian tribes that interacted with Muhammad</a>, the most prominent was the <a href="/wiki/Quraysh" title="Quraysh">Quraysh</a>. The Quraysh subclan, the <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hashim" title="Banu Hashim">Banu Hashim</a>, was the clan of Muhammad. During the early Muslim conquests and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a>, the political rulers of Islam were exclusively members of the Quraysh.
</p><p>The Arab presence in Iran did not begin with the <a href="/wiki/Arab_conquest_of_Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab conquest of Persia">Arab conquest of Persia</a> in 633 CE. For centuries, Iranian rulers had maintained contacts with Arabs outside their borders, dealt with Arab subjects and client states (such as those of Iraq and Yemen), and settled Arab tribesmen in various parts of the Iranian plateau. It follows that the "Arab" conquests and settlements were by no means the exclusive work of Arabs from the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> and the tribesmen of inner Arabia. The Arab infiltration into Iran began before the Muslim conquests and continued as a result of the joint exertions of the civilized Arabs (ahl al-madar) as well as the desert Arabs (ahl al-wabar).<sup id="cite_ref-IranicaDaniel_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IranicaDaniel-112">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> The largest group of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Arabs" title="Iranian Arabs">Iranian Arabs</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Ahwazi_Arabs" title="Ahwazi Arabs">Ahwazi Arabs</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Banu_Ka%27b" title="Banu Ka&#39;b">Banu Ka'b</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bani_Turuf" title="Bani Turuf">Bani Turuf</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Musha%27sha%27iyyah" title="Musha&#39;sha&#39;iyyah">Musha'sha'iyyah</a> sect. Smaller groups are the <a href="/wiki/Khamseh" title="Khamseh">Khamseh</a> nomads in <a href="/wiki/Fars_Province" title="Fars Province">Fars Province</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Khorasan" title="Arabs in Khorasan">Arabs in Khorasan</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg/220px-AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg" width="220" height="157" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg/330px-AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/ba/AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="285" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:AleppoEmirMudhem.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Post-card of Emir Mejhem ibn Meheid, chief of the <a href="/wiki/%60Anazzah" class="mw-redirect" title="`Anazzah">Anaza</a> tribe near <a href="/wiki/Aleppo" title="Aleppo">Aleppo</a> with his sons after being decorated with the Croix de Légion d'honneur on 20 September 1920</div></div></div>
<p>The Arabs of the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a> are traditionally divided into <a href="/wiki/Qays_and_Yaman_tribes" class="mw-redirect" title="Qays and Yaman tribes">Qays and Yaman tribes</a>. This tribal division is likewise taken to date to the Umayyad period.
The Yemen trace their origin to South Arabia or <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>; they include <a href="/wiki/Banu_Kalb" title="Banu Kalb">Banu Kalb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kindah" title="Kindah">Kindah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> Since the 1834 <a href="/wiki/Peasants%27_revolt_in_Palestine" title="Peasants&#39; revolt in Palestine">Peasants' revolt in Palestine</a>, the Arabic-speaking population of Palestine has shed its formerly tribal structure and emerged as the <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinians</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>.
</p><p>Native Jordanians are either descended from <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouins</a> (of which, 6% live a nomadic lifestyle),<sup id="cite_ref-LowiMiriam_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LowiMiriam-114">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> or from the many deeply rooted non bedouin communities across the country, most notably <a href="/wiki/Al-Salt" title="Al-Salt">Al-Salt</a> city west of <a href="/wiki/Amman" title="Amman">Amman</a> which was at the time of Emirate the largest urban settlement east of the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a>. Along with indigenous communities in Al Husn, <a href="/wiki/Aqaba" title="Aqaba">Aqaba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irbid" title="Irbid">Irbid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Karak" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Karak">Al Karak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madaba" title="Madaba">Madaba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jerash" title="Jerash">Jerash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ajloun" title="Ajloun">Ajloun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fuheis" title="Fuheis">Fuheis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pella" title="Pella">Pella</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> In Jordan, there is no official census data for how many inhabitants have <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Palestinian people">Palestinian</a> roots but they are estimated to constitute half of the population,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MRPalestinians_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MRPalestinians-117">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> which in 2008 amounted to about 3 million.<sup id="cite_ref-MRPalestinians_117-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MRPalestinians-117">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics put their number at 3.24 million in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-PCBSJordan_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PCBSJordan-118">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Old_Bedouin,_aged_over_112_years,_and_his_Wife._(1918)_-_TIMEA.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg/220px-The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg" width="220" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg/330px-The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg/440px-The_Old_Bedouin%2C_aged_over_112_years%2C_and_his_Wife._%281918%29_-_TIMEA.jpg 2x" data-file-width="976" data-file-height="885" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Old_Bedouin,_aged_over_112_years,_and_his_Wife._(1918)_-_TIMEA.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Old Bedouin man and his wife in Egypt, 1918</div></div></div>
<p>The Bedouins of western Egypt and eastern Libya are traditionally divided into <a href="/wiki/Sa%CA%BFada_and_Murabtin" title="Saʿada and Murabtin">Saʿada and Murabtin</a>, the Saʿada having higher social status. This may derive from a historical feudal system in which the Murabtin were vassals to the Saʿada
In <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, there are numerous Arabic-speaking tribes, including the <a href="/wiki/Shaigya" class="mw-redirect" title="Shaigya">Shaigya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ja%27alin" class="mw-redirect" title="Ja&#39;alin">Ja'alin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shukria_tribe" class="mw-redirect" title="Shukria tribe">Shukria</a>, who are ancestrally related to the <a href="/wiki/Nubian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nubian people">Nubians</a>. These groups are collectively known as <a href="/wiki/Sudanese_Arabs" title="Sudanese Arabs">Sudanese Arabs</a>. In addition, there are other Afroasiatic-speaking populations, such as <a href="/wiki/Copts" title="Copts">Copts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beja_people" title="Beja people">Beja</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chief_of_Mascara.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Chief_of_Mascara.jpg/220px-Chief_of_Mascara.jpg" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Chief_of_Mascara.jpg/330px-Chief_of_Mascara.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Chief_of_Mascara.jpg/440px-Chief_of_Mascara.jpg 2x" data-file-width="692" data-file-height="512" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Chief_of_Mascara.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Commander and Amir of <a href="/wiki/Mascara,_Algeria" title="Mascara, Algeria">Mascara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hilal" title="Banu Hilal">Banu Hilal</a></div></div></div>
<p>The medieval <a href="/wiki/Arab_slave_trade" title="Arab slave trade">Arab slave trade</a> in the Sudan drove a wedge between the Arabic-speaking groups and the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Nilotic_peoples" title="Nilotic peoples">Nilotic</a> populations. <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_contemporary_Africa" title="Slavery in contemporary Africa">Slavery</a> substantially persists today along these lines.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> It has contributed to ethnic conflict in the region, such as the <a href="/wiki/Sudanese_conflict_in_South_Kordofan_and_Blue_Nile" title="Sudanese conflict in South Kordofan and Blue Nile">Sudanese conflict in South Kordofan and Blue Nile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Mali_conflict" title="Northern Mali conflict">Northern Mali conflict</a>, or the <a href="/wiki/Boko_Haram_insurgency" title="Boko Haram insurgency">Boko Haram insurgency</a>.
</p><p>The Arabs of the Maghreb are descendants of Arabian tribes of <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hilal" title="Banu Hilal">Banu Hilal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Banu_Sulaym" title="Banu Sulaym">Banu Sulaym</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Maqil" title="Maqil">Maqil</a> native of <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> and of other tribes native to <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>. Arabs and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>-speakers inhabit plains and cities. The <a href="/wiki/Banu_Hilal" title="Banu Hilal">Banu Hilal</a> spent almost a century in <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> before moving to <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, and another century later some moved to <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, it is logical to think that they are mixed with inhabitants of <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and with <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The total number of Arabic speakers living in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab nations</a> is estimated at 366 million by the <a href="/wiki/CIA_Factbook" class="mw-redirect" title="CIA Factbook">CIA Factbook</a> (as of 2014). The estimated number of Arabs in countries outside the Arab League is estimated at 17.5 million, yielding a total of close to 384 million.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arab_world">Arab world</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Arab world">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png/220px-Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png/330px-Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png/440px-Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png 2x" data-file-width="821" data-file-height="468" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_Density_in_the_Arab_World.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Population density of the Arab world in 2008</div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_Arab_League" title="Charter of the Arab League">Charter of the Arab League</a> (also known as the <i>Pact of the League of Arab States</i>), the League of Arab States is composed of independent Arab states that are signatories to the Charter.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although all Arab states have Arabic as an official language, there are many non-Arabic-speaking populations native to the Arab world. Among these are <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berbers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toubou_people" title="Toubou people">Toubou</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nubians" title="Nubians">Nubians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tadmouri2014-37">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, many Arab countries in the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> have sizable non-Arab immigrant populations (10–30%). Iraq, Bahrain, Kuwait, Qatar, United Arab Emirates and Oman have a Persian speaking minority. The same countries also have Hindi-Urdu speakers and <a href="/wiki/Filipinos" title="Filipinos">Filipinos</a> as sizable minority. Balochi speakers are a good size minority in Oman. Additionally, countries like Bahrain, UAE, Oman and Kuwait have significant non-Arab and non-Muslim minorities (10–20%) like <a href="/wiki/Hindus" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christians" class="mw-redirect" title="Christians">Christians</a> from <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.
</p><p>The table below shows the distribution of populations in the Arab world, as well as the official language(s) within the various Arab states.<sup id="cite_ref-CIAethnic_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIAethnic-123">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="toccolours sortable" style="border-collapse:collapse; margin:auto;">

<td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/23px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/35px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Morocco.svg/45px-Flag_of_Morocco.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a></td>
<td>32,987,206<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook:_Morocco_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook:_Morocco-135">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup></td>
<td>Arabic co-official language with <a href="/wiki/Berber_languages" title="Berber languages">Berber</a>
</td></tr>

<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/23px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png" width="23" height="9" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/35px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/46px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1400" data-file-height="550" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a></td>

<tr>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a></td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
