</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arab_diaspora">Arab diaspora</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Arab diaspora">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">Arab diaspora</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Arabic_neighborhoods" title="List of Arabic neighborhoods">List of Arabic neighborhoods</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Syrian_colony,_Washington_Street.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg/220px-The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg/330px-The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg/440px-The_Syrian_colony%2C_Washington_Street.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="436" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Syrian_colony,_Washington_Street.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Syrian immigrants in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, as depicted in 1895</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arab_diaspora" title="Arab diaspora">Arab diaspora</a> refers to descendants of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab people">Arab</a> <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">immigrants</a> who, voluntarily or as refugees, emigrated from their native lands in non-Arab countries, primarily in <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> and parts of <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Migration" title="International Organization for Migration">International Organization for Migration</a>, there are 13 million first-generation Arab migrants in the world, of which 5.8 million reside in Arab countries. Arab expatriates contribute to the circulation of financial and human capital in the region and thus significantly promote regional development. In 2009, Arab countries received a total of 35.1 billion USD in <a href="/wiki/Remittance" title="Remittance">remittance</a> in-flows and remittances sent to <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> from other Arab countries are 40 to 190 per cent higher than trade revenues between these and other Arab countries.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> The 250,000 strong Lebanese community in <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a> is the largest non-African group in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> Arab traders have long operated in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and along the East Africa's <a href="/wiki/Swahili_coast" title="Swahili coast">Swahili coast</a>. <a href="/wiki/Zanzibar" title="Zanzibar">Zanzibar</a> was once ruled by <a href="/wiki/Omanis" title="Omanis">Omani</a> Arabs.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> Most of the prominent <a href="/wiki/Arab_Indonesians" title="Arab Indonesians">Indonesians</a>, Malaysians, and Singaporeans of Arab descent are <a href="/wiki/Hadhrami_people" title="Hadhrami people">Hadhrami people</a> with origins in southern Yemen in the <a href="/wiki/Hadramawt" class="mw-redirect" title="Hadramawt">Hadramawt</a> coastal region.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg/220px-Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg" width="220" height="312" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg/330px-Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg/440px-Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg 2x" data-file-width="507" data-file-height="720" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Amel_Bent_NRJ_2014.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Amel_Bent" title="Amel Bent">Amel Bent</a>, a French-born Maghrebi pop singer</div></div></div>
<p>There are millions of Arabs living in Europe mostly concentrated in <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> (about 6,000,000 in 2005<sup id="cite_ref-variety.com_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-variety.com-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup>). Most <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_France" title="Arabs in France">Arabs in France</a> are from the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a> but some also come from the <a href="/wiki/Mashreq" class="mw-redirect" title="Mashreq">Mashreq</a> areas of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>. Arabs in France form the second largest <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic group</a> after <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French people</a> of French origin.<sup id="cite_ref-economist.com_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist.com-151">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> (about 800,000<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> to 1,600,000 – 1,800,000<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup>), there have been <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Spain" title="Arabs in Spain">Arabs in Spain</a> since the early 8th century when the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_conquest_of_Hispania" title="Umayyad conquest of Hispania">Umayyad conquest of Hispania</a> created the state of <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (over 1,000,000<sup id="cite_ref-cz-herborn.de_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cz-herborn.de-161">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> (about 680,000<sup id="cite_ref-ISTAT_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISTAT-25">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> (366,769<sup id="cite_ref-Naba11a_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Naba11a-162">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> to 500,000<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup>). <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> (250,000 to 750,000<sup id="cite_ref-Gre1_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gre1-164">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup>), In addition, Greece has people from Arab countries who have the status of refugees (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_civil_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees of the Syrian civil war">refugees of the Syrian civil war</a>) or illegal immigrants trying to immigrate to Western Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Kniffka1995_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kniffka1995-165">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> (210,400<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup>). <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> (180,000<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>). <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> (121,000). And in other <a href="/wiki/European_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="European countries">European countries</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia" title="Republic of Macedonia">Republic of Macedonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Arab_migration_facts_and_figures_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arab_migration_facts_and_figures-168">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> As of late 2015, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> had a population of 78.7 million, with <a href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War">Syrian refugees</a> accounting for 3.1% of that figure based on conservative estimates. Demographic trends indicate that the country already had from 1,500,000<sup id="cite_ref-ChapinMetz_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChapinMetz-169">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> to more than 2,000,000,<sup id="cite_ref-www.aljazeera.com_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.aljazeera.com-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> so <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Turkey's Arab</a> constituency now numbers anywhere from 4.5 to 5.1% of the population. In other words, nearly 4–5 million Arab inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-www.washingtoninstitute.org_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.washingtoninstitute.org-11">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-www.aljazeera.com_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.aljazeera.com-12">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg/220px-Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg/330px-Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg/440px-Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2576" data-file-height="1932" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arab_American_National_Museum.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Arab_American_National_Museum" title="Arab American National Museum">Arab American National Museum</a> in Dearborn, Michigan, the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> of America</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arab_immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Arab immigration to the United States">Arab immigration to the United States</a> began in sizable numbers during the 1880s. Today, it is estimated that nearly 3.7 million Americans trace their roots to an <a href="/wiki/Arab_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab country">Arab country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aaiusa.org_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaiusa.org-171">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arab_Americans" title="Arab Americans">Arab Americans</a> are found in every state, but more than two thirds of them live in just ten states: <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">California</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">Michigan</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York</a>, <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a>, <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ohio" title="Ohio">Ohio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>. Metropolitan <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Detroit" title="Detroit">Detroit</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> are home to one-third of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-aaiusa.org_171-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaiusa.org-171">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> Contrary to popular assumptions or stereotypes, the majority of Arab Americans are native-born, and nearly 82% of Arabs in the U.S. are citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-174">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aai.3cdn.net_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aai.3cdn.net-175">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-aai.3cdn.net_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aai.3cdn.net-175">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> Arabs immigrants began to arrive in <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a> in small numbers in 1882. Their <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a> was relatively limited until 1945, after which time it increased progressively, particularly in the 1960s and thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> According to the website "Who are Arab Canadians," Montreal, the Canadian city with the largest Arab population, has approximately 267,000 Arab inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_(34921333804).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg/220px-06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg/330px-06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg/440px-06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_%2834921333804%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3506" data-file-height="2337" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:06-07-2017_-_Transmiss%C3%A3o_de_Cargo_de_Presidente_da_Rep%C3%BAblica_(34921333804).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a>, the 37th and current President of Brazil, is of Lebanese descent.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Bio_2_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bio_2-181">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> has the largest Arab population outside of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_World" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab World">Arab World</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> Latin America is home to anywhere from 17–25 to 30 million people of Arab descent,<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> which is more than any other <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a> region in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> The Brazilian and Lebanese governments claim there are 7 million Brazilians of Lebanese descent.<sup id="cite_ref-itamaraty1_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itamaraty1-187">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-libano1_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-libano1-188">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> Also, the Brazilian government claims there are 4 million Brazilians of Syrian descent.<sup id="cite_ref-itamaraty1_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itamaraty1-187">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> According to research conducted by <a href="/wiki/IBGE" class="mw-redirect" title="IBGE">IBGE</a> in 2008, covering only the states of Amazonas, Paraíba, São Paulo, Rio Grande do Sul, Mato Grosso and Distrito Federal, 0.9% of white Brazilian respondents said they had family origins in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IBGE2008_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IBGE2008-189">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-saudiaramcoworld1_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-saudiaramcoworld1-190">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dsbra_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dsbra-191">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> Other large Arab communities includes <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> (about 4,500,000<sup id="cite_ref-Fearab.org.ar_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fearab.org.ar-194">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-oni.escuelas.edu.ar_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oni.escuelas.edu.ar-195">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>) The interethnic marriage in the Arab community, regardless of religious affiliation, is very high; most community members have only one parent who has Arab ethnicity.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> (over 1,600,000<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-17">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-thedailybeast.com_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-thedailybeast.com-198">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> (over 1,600,000<sup id="cite_ref-Las_mil_y_una_historias_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Las_mil_y_una_historias-18">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> to 3,200,000<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RandaAchmawi_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RandaAchmawi-201">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> (over 1,100,000<sup id="cite_ref-Ben_Cahoon_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ben_Cahoon-21">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> (over 800,000<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-select.nytimes.com_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-select.nytimes.com-206">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>), and <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central America</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">Honduras</a> (between 150,000 and 200,000).<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> is the fourth largest in the world after those in Israel, Lebanon, and Jordan. <a href="/wiki/Arab_Haitians" title="Arab Haitians">Arab Haitians</a> (a large number of whom live in the capital) are more often than not, concentrated in financial areas where the majority of them establish businesses.<sup id="cite_ref-al-shorfa.com_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-al-shorfa.com-210">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-al-shorfa.com_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-al-shorfa.com-210">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-al-shorfa.com_210-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-al-shorfa.com-210">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg/220px-Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg.png" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg/330px-Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg/440px-Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1155" data-file-height="898" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus_1060_map_en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Georgia and the Caucasus in 1060, during the final decline of the emirate</div></div></div><p>
In 1728, a Russian officer described a group of Arab nomads who populated the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian</a> shores of <a href="/wiki/Mughan_plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughan plain">Mughan</a> (in present-day <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>) and spoke a mixed Turkic-Arabic language.<sup id="cite_ref-Genko_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Genko-211">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> It is believed that these groups migrated to the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> in the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-zelkina_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zelkina-212">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> The 1888 edition of <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a> also mentioned a certain number of Arabs populating the <a href="/wiki/Baku_Governorate" title="Baku Governorate">Baku Governorate</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Baynesp514_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Baynesp514-213">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> They retained an <a href="/wiki/Shirvani_Arabic" title="Shirvani Arabic">Arabic dialect</a> at least into the mid-19th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Bakik_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bakik-214">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> there are nearly 30 settlements still holding the name <i>Arab</i> (for example, <a href="/wiki/%C6%8Fr%C9%99bq%C9%99dim" title="Ərəbqədim">Arabgadim</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C6%8Fr%C9%99boca%C4%9F%C4%B1" title="Ərəbocağı">Arabojaghy</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C6%8Fr%C9%99byengic%C9%99" title="Ərəbyengicə">Arab-Yengija</a>, etc.). From the time of the Arab conquest of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, continuous small-scale Arab migration from various parts of the Arab world occurred in <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>. The majority of these lived in the village of Darvag, to the north-west of <a href="/wiki/Derbent" title="Derbent">Derbent</a>. The latest of these accounts dates to the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-zelkina_212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zelkina-212">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> Most Arab communities in southern Dagestan underwent linguistic <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkicisation</a>, thus nowadays Darvag is a majority-Azeri village.<sup id="cite_ref-Sefer_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sefer-215">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wrum_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wrum-216">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> According to the <i>History of Ibn Khaldun</i>, the Arabs that were once in Central Asia have been either killed or have fled the Tatar invasion of the region, leaving only the locals.<sup id="cite_ref-Khaldun_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khaldun-217">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> However, today many people in Central Asia identify as Arabs. Most <a href="/wiki/Central_Asian_Arabic" title="Central Asian Arabic">Arabs of Central Asia</a> are fully integrated into local populations, and sometimes call themselves the same as locals (for example, <a href="/wiki/T%C4%81jik_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tājik people">Tajiks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uzbeks" title="Uzbeks">Uzbeks</a>) but they use special titles to show their Arab origin such as <a href="/wiki/Sayyid" title="Sayyid">Sayyid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khoja_(Turkestan)" title="Khoja (Turkestan)">Khoja</a> or <a href="/wiki/Siddiqui" title="Siddiqui">Siddiqui</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Owensp184_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Owensp184-218">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala,_Sri_Lanka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/220px-Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/330px-Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/440px-Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2480" data-file-height="1720" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ketchimalai_Mosque-_Beruwala,_Sri_Lanka.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kechimalai Mosque, Beruwala. One of the oldest mosques in Sri Lanka. It is believed to be the site where the first Arabs landed in Sri Lanka.</div></div></div>
<p>There are only two communities in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> which self-identify as Arabs, the <a href="/wiki/Chaush" class="mw-redirect" title="Chaush">Chaush</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan</a> region and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_(Gujarat)" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab (Gujarat)">Chavuse</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> These groups are largely descended from Hadhrami migrants who settled in these two regions in the 18th century. However, neither community still speaks Arabic, although the Chaush have seen re-immigration to the <a href="/wiki/Arab_States_of_the_Persian_Gulf" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab States of the Persian Gulf">Arab States of the Persian Gulf</a> and thus a re-adoption of Arabic.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>, where Arab ancestry is considered prestigious, many communities have origin myths that claim Arab ancestry. These include the <a href="/wiki/Mappilla" class="mw-redirect" title="Mappilla">Mappilla</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Labbai" class="mw-redirect" title="Labbai">Labbai</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> Among <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">North Indian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Pakistan" title="Arabs in Pakistan">Pakistani</a> Arabs, there are groups who claim the status of <a href="/wiki/Sayyid" title="Sayyid">Sayyid</a> and have origin myths that allege descent from <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> The South Asian <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_biradri" class="mw-redirect" title="Iraqi biradri">Iraqi biradri</a> may be considered Arabs because records of their ancestors who migrated from Iraq exist in historical documents. There are about 5,000,000 <a href="/wiki/Native_Indonesians" title="Native Indonesians">Native Indonesians</a> with Arab ancestry.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arab_Indonesians" title="Arab Indonesians">Arab Indonesians</a> are mainly of <a href="/wiki/Hadhrami_people" title="Hadhrami people">Hadrami</a> descent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECribbKahin200418–19_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECribbKahin200418–19-225">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECribbKahin200418–19_225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECribbKahin200418–19-225">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Moors" title="Sri Lankan Moors">Sri Lankan Moors</a> are the third largest ethnic group in <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, comprising 9.23% of the country's total population.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> Some sources trace the ancestry of the Sri Lankan <a href="/wiki/Moors" title="Moors">Moors</a> to Arab traders who settled in Sri Lanka at some time between the 8th and 15th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-TheSundayTimes_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TheSundayTimes-227">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Anthropos_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anthropos-228">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Islamic_Studies_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Islamic_Studies-229">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg/220px-Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg.png" width="220" height="115" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg/330px-Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg/440px-Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1149" data-file-height="599" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Baggara_Arabs_Belt.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Baggara" title="Baggara">Baggara</a> belt</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Afro-Arabs" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Arabs">Afro-Arabs</a> are individuals and groups from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> who are of partial Arab descent. Most Afro-Arabs inhabit the <a href="/wiki/Swahili_Coast" class="mw-redirect" title="Swahili Coast">Swahili Coast</a> in the <a href="/wiki/African_Great_Lakes" title="African Great Lakes">African Great Lakes</a> region, although some can also be found in parts of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Romero_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Romero-230">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gunnar_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gunnar-231">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> Large numbers of Arabs migrated to <a href="/wiki/West_Africa" title="West Africa">West Africa</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/C%C3%B4te_d%27Ivoire" class="mw-redirect" title="Côte d&#39;Ivoire">Côte d'Ivoire</a> (home to over 100,000 Lebanese),<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Senegal" title="Senegal">Senegal</a> (roughly 30,000 Lebanese),<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a> (roughly 10,000 Lebanese today; about 30,000 prior to the outbreak of <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone_Civil_War" title="Sierra Leone Civil War">civil war</a> in 1991), <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> Since the end of the civil war in 2002, <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese</a> traders have become re-established in Sierra Leone.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> The Arabs of Chad occupy northern Cameroon and Nigeria (where they are sometimes known as Shuwa), and extend as a belt across Chad and into Sudan, where they are called the <a href="/wiki/Baggara" title="Baggara">Baggara</a> grouping of <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> ethnic groups inhabiting the portion of Africa's <a href="/wiki/Sahel" title="Sahel">Sahel</a>. The Chadian Arabs are (2,391,000 to 2,500,000<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> (289,000<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Cameroon" title="Cameroon">Cameroon</a> (171,000), <a href="/wiki/Niger" title="Niger">Niger</a> (150,000<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup>), and the <a href="/wiki/Central_African_Republic" title="Central African Republic">Central African Republic</a> (107,000).<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Arabian_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian mythology">Arabian mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Muslims" title="Arab Muslims">Arab Muslims</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá&#39;í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG/220px-Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG/330px-Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG/440px-Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3744" data-file-height="3744" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nemesis_Allat_and_dedicater-MBA_Lyon-IMG_0557.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bas-relief: <a href="/wiki/Nemesis_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Nemesis (mythology)">Nemesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/All%C4%81t" class="mw-redirect" title="Allāt">Allāt</a> and the dedicator</div></div></div>
<p>Arabs are mostly Muslims with a <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> majority and a <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> minority, one exception being the <a href="/wiki/Ibadi" title="Ibadi">Ibadis</a>, who predominate in <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ahmadi_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahmadi-243">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christians</a> generally follow <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Churches">Eastern Churches</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Orthodox">Greek Orthodox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Catholic">Greek Catholic</a> churches, though a minority of <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant Church">Protestant Church</a> followers also exists.<sup id="cite_ref-Christi_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christi-244">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> There are also Arab communities consisting of <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baha%27i" class="mw-redirect" title="Baha&#39;i">Baha'is</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia">Before the coming of Islam</a>, most Arabs followed a pagan religion with a number of deities, including <a href="/wiki/Hubal" title="Hubal">Hubal</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Hubal_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hubal-247">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wadd" title="Wadd">Wadd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-l%C4%81t" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-lāt">Allāt</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-248">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Man%C4%81t" title="Manāt">Manat</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Uzza" class="mw-redirect" title="Uzza">Uzza</a>. A few individuals, the <i><a href="/wiki/Hanif" title="Hanif">hanifs</a></i>, had apparently rejected <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheism</a> in favor of <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a> unaffiliated with any particular religion. Some tribes had converted to Christianity or Judaism. The most prominent Arab Christian kingdoms were the <a href="/wiki/Ghassanid" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghassanid">Ghassanid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lakhmid" class="mw-redirect" title="Lakhmid">Lakhmid</a> kingdoms.<sup id="cite_ref-Marib_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marib-249">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> When the <a href="/wiki/Himyarite" class="mw-redirect" title="Himyarite">Himyarite</a> king converted to <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> in the late 4th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Hima_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hima-250">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> the elites of the other prominent Arab kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Kindites" class="mw-redirect" title="Kindites">Kindites</a>, being Himyirite vassals, apparently also converted (at least partly). With the expansion of Islam, polytheistic Arabs were rapidly <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">Islamized</a>, and polytheistic traditions gradually disappeared.<sup id="cite_ref-MSNU_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MSNU-251">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EncyRe_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EncyRe-252">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kaaba_at_night.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Kaaba_at_night.jpg/220px-Kaaba_at_night.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Kaaba_at_night.jpg/330px-Kaaba_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Kaaba_at_night.jpg/440px-Kaaba_at_night.jpg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="720" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kaaba_at_night.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Holiest_sites_in_Islam" title="Holiest sites in Islam">holiest place in Islam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> in <a href="/wiki/Al-Haram_Mosque" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Haram Mosque">Al-Haram Mosque</a>, is located in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, the Hejazi region of <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a></div></div></div>
<p>Today, Sunni Islam dominates in most areas, overwhelmingly so in North Africa and the Horn of Africa. Shia Islam is dominant among the Arab population in <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a> and southern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> while northern Iraq is mostly Sunni. Substantial Shia populations exist in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Shia_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shia-253">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> northern <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and Al-Batinah Region in <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>. There are small numbers of <a href="/wiki/Ibadi" title="Ibadi">Ibadi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-denominational Muslims">non-denominational Muslims</a> too.<sup id="cite_ref-ahmadi_243-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahmadi-243">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> community is concentrated in Lebanon, Syria, Israel and Jordan. Many <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> claim independence from other major religions in the area and consider their religion more of a philosophy. Their books of worship are called <a href="/wiki/Kitab_Al_Hikma" class="mw-redirect" title="Kitab Al Hikma">Kitab Al Hikma</a> (Epistles of Wisdom). They believe in reincarnation and pray to five messengers from God. In Israel, the Druze have a <i>status aparte</i> from the general Arab population, treated as a separate ethno-religious community.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg/220px-Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg/330px-Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg/440px-Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1038" data-file-height="777" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Orthodox_church_in_Amman1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Christianity_in_Jordan" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox Christianity in Jordan">Greek Orthodox</a> Church during a snow storm in <a href="/wiki/Amman" title="Amman">Amman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a></div></div></div>
<p>Christianity had a prominent presence In <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">pre-Islamic Arabia</a> among several Arab communities, including the <a href="/wiki/Bahrani_people" title="Bahrani people">Bahrani people</a> of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Arabia" title="Eastern Arabia">Eastern Arabia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Christian_community_of_Najran" title="Christian community of Najran">Christian community of Najran</a>, in parts of <a href="/wiki/Yemen#Ancient_history" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>, and among certain northern Arabian tribes such as the <a href="/wiki/Ghassanids" title="Ghassanids">Ghassanids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lakhmids" title="Lakhmids">Lakhmids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taghlib" title="Taghlib">Taghlib</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banu_Amela" title="Banu Amela">Banu Amela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banu_Judham" title="Banu Judham">Banu Judham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanukhids" title="Tanukhids">Tanukhids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tayy" title="Tayy">Tayy</a>. In the early Christian centuries, Arabia was sometimes known as <i>Arabia heretica</i>, due to its being "well known as a breeding-ground for heterodox interpretations of Christianity."<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> Christians make up 5.5% of the population of Western Asia and North Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-Pacini_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pacini-255">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> A sizeable share of those are Arab Christians proper, and affiliated Arabic-speaking populations of Copts and Maronites. In Lebanon, Christians number about 40.5% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook:_Lebanon_132-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook:_Lebanon-132">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> In Syria, Christians make up 10% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook:_Syria_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook:_Syria-142">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a>, Christians make up 8% and 0.7% of the populations, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-FactbookGazaStrip_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FactbookGazaStrip-256">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FactbookWestBank_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FactbookWestBank-257">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> In Egypt, Coptic Christians number about 10% of the population. In Iraq, Christians constitute 0.1% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> In Israel, Arab Christians constitute 2.1% (roughly 9% of the Arab population).<sup id="cite_ref-WFIS_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WFIS-259">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> Arab Christians make up 8% of the population of <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WFJord_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WFJord-260">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> Most <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a> Arabs are Christian,<sup id="cite_ref-AAIUSA_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAIUSA-261">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> so are about half of the Arabs in <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> who come particularly from Lebanon, Syria and Palestine. One well known member of this religious and ethnic community is <a href="/wiki/Abo_of_Tiflis" title="Abo of Tiflis">Saint Abo</a>, martyr and the patron saint of <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> Arab Christians also live in holy Christian cities such as <a href="/wiki/Nazareth" title="Nazareth">Nazareth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Quarter" title="Christian Quarter">Christian Quarter</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Old_City_of_Jerusalem" class="mw-redirect" title="Old City of Jerusalem">Old City of Jerusalem</a> and many other villages with holy Christian sites.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">Arab culture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg/170px-ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg" width="170" height="122" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg/255px-ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg/340px-ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="575" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:ManuscriptAbbasid.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An Abbasid-era Arabic manuscript</div></div></div>
  <table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding-top:0.4em;line-height:1.2em">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Arab_culture" title="Category:Arab culture">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="fn org country-name adr" style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;padding-top:0;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em;background:#CCCCFF; display:block;margin-bottom:0.3em"><a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">Arab culture</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0.2em 0 0.4em"><a href="/wiki/File:Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Hadîth Bayâd wa Riyâd - BAV Ar368 f10r - Garden scene.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg/260px-Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg" width="260" height="164" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg/390px-Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a5/Had%C3%AEth_Bay%C3%A2d_wa_Riy%C3%A2d_-_BAV_Ar368_f10r_-_Garden_scene.jpg 2x" data-file-width="469" data-file-height="295" /></a></td></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em;padding-bottom:0; margin-bottom:0;">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:lavender; white-space:nowrap; font-size:12.5px; text-align:center; border-top:solid 1px #aaa; font-variant: small-caps;"><a href="/wiki/Category:Arabic_architecture" title="Category:Arabic architecture">Architecture</a></div><div class="NavContent plainlist" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center;border-top:solid 1px #aaa;"><div class="hlist">
<p><b>Styles</b>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Architecture_of_ancient_Yemen" title="Category:Architecture of ancient Yemen">Architecture of ancient Yemen</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nabataean_architecture" title="Nabataean architecture">Nabataean architecture</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Umayyad_architecture" title="Umayyad architecture">Umayyad architecture</a></li>

<p><b>Features </b>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Ablaq" title="Ablaq">Ablaq</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Sahn" title="Sahn">Sahn</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tadelakt" title="Tadelakt">Tadelakt</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vaulting" class="mw-redirect" title="Vaulting">Vaulting</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Alfiz" title="Alfiz">Alfiz</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arabesque_(Islamic_art)" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabesque (Islamic art)">Arabesque</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Girih" title="Girih">Girih</a></li>

</div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;padding-top:0;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Arab_culture" title="Template:Arab culture"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Arab_culture" title="Template talk:Arab culture"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Arab_culture&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table><p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic culture">Arabic culture</a> is the culture of Arab people, from the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> in the west to the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> in the east, and from the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. <a href="/wiki/Language" title="Language">Language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Literature" title="Literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gastronomy" title="Gastronomy">gastronomy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art" title="Art">art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture" title="Architecture">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music" title="Music">music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spirituality" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philosophy" title="Philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mysticism</a> (etc.) are all part of the cultural heritage of the Arabs.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Arabs share <a href="/wiki/Basic_belief" title="Basic belief">basic beliefs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Values" class="mw-redirect" title="Values">values</a> that cross national and <a href="/wiki/Social" title="Social">social</a> class boundaries. Social attitudes have remained constant because Arab society is more conservative and demands conformity from its members.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Language">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg/220px-Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg/330px-Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg/440px-Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Learning_Arabic_calligraphy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Arabic_calligraphy" title="Arabic calligraphy">Arabic calligraphy</a></div></div></div>
<p>Another important and unifying characteristic of Arabs is a common <a href="/wiki/Language" title="Language">language</a>. <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Semitic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Semitic language">Semitic language</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afro-Asiatic Family</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> Evidence of its first use appears in accounts of wars in 853 BCE. It also became widely used in trade and commerce. Arabic also is a <a href="/wiki/Liturgy#Islam" title="Liturgy">liturgical</a> language of 1.7 billion <a href="/wiki/Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslims">Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pewmuslim42_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pewmuslim42-266">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Arabic is one of six <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">official languages of the United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> It is revered as the language that <a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">God</a> chose to reveal the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pewmuslim4_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pewmuslim4-269">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Arabic has developed into at least two distinct forms. <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a> is the form of the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic language</a> used in literary texts from <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid</a> times (7th to 9th centuries). It is based on the medieval dialects of <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">Arab tribes</a>. <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Modern Standard Arabic</a> (MSA) is the direct descendant used today throughout the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> in writing and in formal speaking, for example, prepared speeches, some radio broadcasts, and non-entertainment content,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBin-Muqbil200614_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBin-Muqbil200614-271">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Lexis_(linguistics)" title="Lexis (linguistics)">lexis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stylistics_(linguistics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Stylistics (linguistics)">stylistics</a> of <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Modern Standard Arabic</a> are different from <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a>. Colloquial Arabic, an informal spoken language, varies by dialect from region to region; various forms of the language are in use today and provide an important force for Arab cohesion.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mythology">Mythology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Mythology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabian_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian mythology">Arabian mythology</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg/170px-Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg" width="170" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg/255px-Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3b/Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg 2x" data-file-width="322" data-file-height="480" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Illustration_of_Aladdin_Flying_Away_with_Two_People_from_the_Arabian_Nights.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Aladdin" title="Aladdin">Aladdin</a> flying away with two people, from the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Nights" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian Nights">Arabian Nights</a>, c. 1900</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic mythology">Arabic mythology</a> comprises the ancient beliefs of the Arabs.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> Prior to Islam the Kaaba of Mecca was covered in symbols representing the myriad demons, djinn, demigods, or simply tribal gods and other assorted deities which represented the polytheistic culture of pre-Islamic.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> It has been inferred from this plurality an exceptionally broad context in which mythology could flourish. The most popular beasts and demons of Arabian mythology are <a href="/wiki/Bahamut" title="Bahamut">Bahamut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dandan" title="Dandan">Dandan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Falak_(Arabian_legend)" title="Falak (Arabian legend)">Falak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghoul" title="Ghoul">Ghoul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinn_(mythology)" title="Hinn (mythology)">Hinn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jinn" title="Jinn">Jinn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karkadann" title="Karkadann">Karkadann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marid" title="Marid">Marid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nasnas" title="Nasnas">Nasnas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qareen" title="Qareen">Qareen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roc_(mythology)" title="Roc (mythology)">Roc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shadhavar" title="Shadhavar">Shadhavar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Werehyena" title="Werehyena">Werehyena</a> and other assorted creatures which represented the profoundly <a href="/wiki/Polytheistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Polytheistic">polytheistic</a> environment of pre-Islamic.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The most obvious symbol of Arabian mythology is the <a href="/wiki/Jinn" title="Jinn">Jinn</a> or genie.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Jinns are supernatural beings of varying degrees of power. They possess free will (that is, they can choose to be good or evil) and come in two flavors. There are the Marids, usually described as the most powerful type of Jinn. These are the type of genie with the ability to grant wishes to humans. However, granting these wishes is not free. The Quran says that the <i>jinn</i> were created from "mārijin min nar" (<i>smokeless fire</i> or <i>a mixture of fire</i>; scholars explained, this is the part of the flame, which mixed with <i>the blackness of fire</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> They are not purely spiritual, but are also physical in nature, being able to interact in a tactile manner with people and objects and likewise be acted upon. The <i>jinn</i>, humans, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_angels" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic view of angels">angels</a> make up the known <a href="/wiki/Sapience" class="mw-redirect" title="Sapience">sapient</a> creations of <a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">God</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Ghoul" title="Ghoul">ghoul</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Monster" title="Monster">monster</a> or <a href="/wiki/Evil_spirit" class="mw-redirect" title="Evil spirit">evil spirit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arabic_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic mythology">Arabic mythology</a>, associated with graveyards and consuming human flesh,<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> demonic being believed to inhabit burial grounds and other deserted places. In ancient Arabic folklore, ghūls belonged to a diabolic class of jinn (spirits) and were said to be the offspring of Iblīs, the prince of darkness in Islam. They were capable of constantly changing form, but their presence was always recognizable by their unalterable sign—ass's hooves.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> which describes the <i>ghūl</i> of Arabic folklore. The <i>ghul</i> is a devilish type of <a href="/wiki/Genie" class="mw-redirect" title="Genie">jinn</a> believed to be sired by <a href="/wiki/Iblis" title="Iblis">Iblis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_literature" title="Arabic literature">Arabic literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Al-Jahiz.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Al-Jahiz.jpg/170px-Al-Jahiz.jpg" width="170" height="254" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Al-Jahiz.jpg/255px-Al-Jahiz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Al-Jahiz.jpg/340px-Al-Jahiz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="940" data-file-height="1404" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Al-Jahiz.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A giraffe from the <i>Kitāb al-Ḥayawān</i> (<i>Book of the Animals</i>), an important scientific treatise by the 9th century Arab writer <a href="/wiki/Al-Jahiz" title="Al-Jahiz">Al-Jahiz</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Al-Jahiz" title="Al-Jahiz">Al-Jahiz</a> (born 776, in <a href="/wiki/Basra" title="Basra">Basra</a> – December 868/January 869) was an Arab prose writer and author of works of literature, <a href="/wiki/Mu%27tazili" class="mw-redirect" title="Mu&#39;tazili">Mu'tazili</a> theology, and politico-religious polemics. A leading scholar in the Abassid Caliphate, his canon includes two hundred books on various subjects, including <a href="/wiki/Arabic_grammar" title="Arabic grammar">Arabic grammar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zoology" title="Zoology">zoology</a>, poetry, lexicography, and <a href="/wiki/Rhetoric" title="Rhetoric">rhetoric</a>. Of his writings, only thirty books survive. Al-Jāḥiẓ was also one of the first Arabian writers to suggest a complete overhaul of the language's grammatical system, though this would not be undertaken until his fellow linguist <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Ma%E1%B8%8D%C4%81%CA%BE" title="Ibn Maḍāʾ">Ibn Maḍāʾ</a> took up the matter two hundred years later.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There is a small remnant of <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_poetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-Islamic poetry">pre-Islamic poetry</a>, but Arabic literature predominantly emerges in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Age of Islam">Golden Age of Islam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Literary_Arabic" class="mw-redirect" title="Literary Arabic">Literary Arabic</a> is derived from <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a>, based on the language of the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> as it was analyzed by <a href="/wiki/Arabic_grammarians" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic grammarians">Arabic grammarians</a> beginning in the 8th century.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg/170px-Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg" width="170" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg/255px-Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg/340px-Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg 2x" data-file-width="921" data-file-height="1199" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Badr_al-Din_Lu%27lu%27.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Illustration from <i><a href="/wiki/Kitab_al-Aghani" title="Kitab al-Aghani">Kitab al-Aghani</a></i> (<i>Book of Songs</i>), by <a href="/wiki/Abu_al-Faraj_al-Isfahani" title="Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani">Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani</a>. The 14th-century historian <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun" title="Ibn Khaldun">Ibn Khaldun</a> called the <i>Book of Songs</i> the register of the Arabs.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>A large portion of Arabic literature before the 20th century is in the form of <a href="/wiki/Arabic_poetry" title="Arabic poetry">poetry</a>, and even prose from this period is either filled with snippets of poetry or is in the form of <i><a href="/wiki/Saj_(literature)" class="mw-redirect" title="Saj (literature)">saj</a></i> or rhymed prose.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup>
The <i><a href="/wiki/Ghazal" title="Ghazal">ghazal</a></i> or love poem had a long history being at times tender and chaste and at other times rather explicit.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Sufi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sufi">Sufi</a> tradition the love poem would take on a wider, <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religious</a> importance. <a href="/wiki/Arabic_epic_literature" title="Arabic epic literature">Arabic epic literature</a> was much less common than poetry, and presumably originates in oral tradition, written down from the 14th century or so. <a href="/wiki/Maqama" title="Maqama">Maqama</a> or <a href="/wiki/Rhymed_prose" title="Rhymed prose">rhymed prose</a> is intermediate between poetry and <a href="/wiki/Prose" title="Prose">prose</a>, and also between fiction and non-fiction.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maqama" title="Maqama">Maqama</a> was an incredibly popular form of Arabic literature, being one of the few forms which continued to be written during the decline of Arabic in the 17th and 18th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa,_c._1911.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa%2C_c._1911.jpg/170px-Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa%2C_c._1911.jpg" width="170" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa%2C_c._1911.jpg/255px-Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa%2C_c._1911.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa%2C_c._1911.jpg 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="372" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Khalil_Gibran_-_Autorretrato_con_musa,_c._1911.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Self portrait of renowned Lebanese poet/writer <a href="/wiki/Khalil_Gibran" class="mw-redirect" title="Khalil Gibran">Khalil Gibran</a></div></div></div>
<p>Arabic literature and <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">culture</a> declined significantly after the 13th century, to the benefit of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language" title="Ottoman Turkish language">Turkish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian</a>. A modern revival took place beginning in the 19th century, alongside <a href="/wiki/National_awakenings_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="National awakenings under the Ottoman Empire">resistance against Ottoman rule</a>. The literary revival is known as <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Nahda" title="Al-Nahda">al-Nahda</a></i> in Arabic, and was centered in <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>. Two distinct trends can be found in the <i>nahda</i> period of revival.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> The first was a neo-classical movement which sought to rediscover the literary traditions of the past, and was influenced by traditional literary genres—such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Maqama" title="Maqama">maqama</a></i>—and works like <i><a href="/wiki/One_Thousand_and_One_Nights" title="One Thousand and One Nights">One Thousand and One Nights</a></i>. In contrast, a modernist movement began by translating Western modernist works—primarily novels—into Arabic.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup> A tradition of <a href="/wiki/Modern_Arabic_poetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern Arabic poetry">modern Arabic poetry</a> was established by writers such as <a href="/wiki/Francis_Marrash" title="Francis Marrash">Francis Marrash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shawqi" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmad Shawqi">Ahmad Shawqi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hafiz_Ibrahim" class="mw-redirect" title="Hafiz Ibrahim">Hafiz Ibrahim</a>. Iraqi poet <a href="/wiki/Badr_Shakir_al-Sayyab" title="Badr Shakir al-Sayyab">Badr Shakir al-Sayyab</a> is considered to be the originator of free verse in <a href="/wiki/Arabic_poetry" title="Arabic poetry">Arabic poetry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gastronomy">Gastronomy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Gastronomy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_cuisine" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic cuisine">Arabic cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Petra_metzes.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Petra_metzes.jpg/220px-Petra_metzes.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Petra_metzes.jpg/330px-Petra_metzes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Petra_metzes.jpg/440px-Petra_metzes.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Petra_metzes.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A large plate of <a href="/wiki/Meze" title="Meze">Mezes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Petra" title="Petra">Petra</a>, Jordan</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_cuisine" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic cuisine">Arabic cuisine</a> is the cuisine of the Arab people.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> The cuisines are often centuries old and resemble and culture of great trading in spices, herbs, and foods. The three main regions, also known as the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mashriq" title="Mashriq">Mashriq</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf" title="Arab states of the Persian Gulf">Khaleej</a> have many similarities, but also many unique traditions. These kitchens have been influenced by the climate, cultivating possibilities, as well as trading possibilities. The kitchens of the Maghreb and <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a> are relatively young kitchens which were developed over the past centuries. The kitchen from the Khaleej region is a very old kitchen. The kitchens can be divided into the <a href="/wiki/Urban_area" title="Urban area">urban</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rural_area" title="Rural area">rural</a> kitchens.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab cuisine</a> mostly follows one of three culinary traditions – from the Maghreb, the Levant or the <a href="/wiki/Arab_states_of_the_Persian_Gulf" title="Arab states of the Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf states</a>. In the Maghreb countries (<a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tunisia" title="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>) traditional main meals are <a href="/wiki/Tajine" title="Tajine">tajines</a> or dishes using <a href="/wiki/Couscous" title="Couscous">couscous</a>.
