In the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a> (<a href="/wiki/Palestine_(region)" title="Palestine (region)">Palestine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>) main meals usually start with <a href="/wiki/Meze" title="Meze">mezze</a> – small dishes of dips and other items which are eaten with bread. This is typically followed by skewers of grilled lamb or chicken. Gulf cuisine, tends to be more highly spiced with more use of rice. Sometimes a lamb is roasted and served whole.<sup id="cite_ref-Food_and_recipes_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Food_and_recipes-300">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>One will find the following items on most dishes; <a href="/wiki/Cinnamon" title="Cinnamon">Cinnamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">Fish</a> (in coastal areas), <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">Garlic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sheep" title="Sheep">Lamb</a> (or veal), Mild to hot <a href="/wiki/Sauces" class="mw-redirect" title="Sauces">sauces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">Mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">Onion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">Rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saffron" title="Saffron">Saffron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sesame" title="Sesame">Sesame</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">Yogurt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spices" class="mw-redirect" title="Spices">Spices</a> due to heavy trading between the two regions. <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">Tea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thyme" title="Thyme">Thyme</a> (or oregano), <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">Turmeric</a>, Variety of <a href="/wiki/Fruit" title="Fruit">fruits</a> (primarily citrus), Variety of <a href="/wiki/Vegetable" title="Vegetable">vegetables</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Cucumbers" class="mw-redirect" title="Cucumbers">cucumbers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eggplants" class="mw-redirect" title="Eggplants">eggplants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lettuce" title="Lettuce">lettuce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tomato" title="Tomato">tomato</a>, <a href="/wiki/Capsicum_annuum" title="Capsicum annuum">green pepper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Green_beans" class="mw-redirect" title="Green beans">green beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zucchini" title="Zucchini">zucchini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parsley" title="Parsley">parsley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Food_and_recipes_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Food_and_recipes-300">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Art">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic art">Arabic art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nabataean_art" title="Nabataean art">Nabataean art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_miniature" title="Arabic miniature">Arabic miniature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arabesque" title="Arabesque">Arabesque</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arabesques_alhambra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Arabesques_alhambra.jpg/150px-Arabesques_alhambra.jpg" width="150" height="225" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Arabesques_alhambra.jpg/225px-Arabesques_alhambra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Arabesques_alhambra.jpg/300px-Arabesques_alhambra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3056" data-file-height="4592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arabesques_alhambra.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mosaic and arabesque on a wall of the Myrtle court in <a href="/wiki/Alhambra" title="Alhambra">Alhambra</a>, Granada.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic art">Arabic art</a> takes on many forms, though it is <a href="/wiki/Jewelry" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewelry">jewelry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textiles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Architecture" title="Architecture">architecture</a> that are the most well-known. It is generally split up by different eras, among them being <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Arabic_alphabet" title="History of the Arabic alphabet">early Arabic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_medieval" class="mw-redirect" title="Early medieval">early medieval</a>, <a href="/wiki/Late_medieval" class="mw-redirect" title="Late medieval">late medieval</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">late Arabic</a>, and finally, current Arabic. One thing to remember is that many times a particular style from one era may continue into the next with few changes, while some have a drastic transformation. This may seem like a strange grouping of art mediums, but they are all closely related.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg/220px-Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg/330px-Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg/440px-Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2024" data-file-height="1585" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Arabischer_Maler_um_1335_003.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Arabic_miniature" title="Arabic miniature">Arabic miniature</a> dibicting <a href="/wiki/Al-Harith_ibn_Jabalah" title="Al-Harith ibn Jabalah">Al-Harith</a> from <a href="/wiki/Maqama" title="Maqama">Maqamat</a> of <a href="/wiki/Al-Hariri_of_Basra" title="Al-Hariri of Basra">al-Hariri</a></div></div></div>
<p>Arabic writing is done from right to left, and was generally written in dark inks, with certain things embellished with special colored inks (red, green, gold). In early Arabic and <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">early Medieval</a>, writing was typically done on parchment made of animal skin. The ink showed up very well on it, and occasionally the parchment was dyed a separate color and brighter ink was used (this was only for special projects). The name given to the form of writing in early times was called <a href="/wiki/Kufic" title="Kufic">Kufic</a> script.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_miniature" title="Arabic miniature">Arabic miniatures</a> are small <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">paintings</a> on <a href="/wiki/Paper" title="Paper">paper</a>, whether book illustrations or separate works of art. <a href="/wiki/Arabic_miniature" title="Arabic miniature">Arabic miniature</a> art dates to the late 7th century. <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arabs</a> depended on such art not only to satisfy their artistic taste, but also for <a href="/wiki/Scientific_explanation" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientific explanation">scientific explanations</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Arabesque" title="Arabesque">Arabesque</a> is a form of artistic decoration consisting of "surface decorations based on rhythmic linear patterns of scrolling and interlacing foliage, tendrils" or plain lines,<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> often combined with other elements. Another definition is "Foliate ornament, typically using leaves, derived from stylised <a href="/wiki/Half-palmette" class="mw-redirect" title="Half-palmette">half-palmettes</a>, which were combined with spiralling stems".<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> It usually consists of a single design which can be 'tiled' or seamlessly repeated as many times as desired.<sup id="cite_ref-RobinsonIllustrated_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobinsonIllustrated-307">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic architecture">Arabic architecture</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG/220px-Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG/330px-Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG/440px-Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1476" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mezquita-Catedral_de_Cordoba_04.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Mosque%E2%80%93Cathedral_of_C%C3%B3rdoba" title="Mosque–Cathedral of Córdoba">Mosque-Cathedral of Cordóba</a>, built by <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Rahman_I" title="Abd al-Rahman I">Abd al Rahman I</a> in 987</div></div></div>
<p>Arabic Architecture has a deep diverse history, it dates to the dawn of the history in <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">pre-Islamic Arabia</a> and includes various styles from the <a href="/wiki/Nabataean_architecture" title="Nabataean architecture">Nabataean architecture</a> to the old yet still used architecture in various regions of the Arab world. Each of it phases largely
an extension of the earlier phase, it left also heavy impact on the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">architecture</a> of other nations. Arab Architecture also encompasses a wide range of both secular and religious styles from the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Islam" title="History of Islam">foundation of Islam</a> to the present day. Some parts of its religious architectures raised by Muslim Arabs were influenced by cultures of <a href="/wiki/Roman_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman architecture">Roman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine</a> and cultures of other lands which the <a href="/wiki/Early_Muslim_conquests" title="Early Muslim conquests">Arab conquered</a> in the 7th and 8th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-Krautheimer_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krautheimer-309">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab-Norman_culture#Norman-Arab-Byzantine_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab-Norman culture">Arab-Norman architecture</a> combined Occidental features, such as the Classical pillars and friezes, with typical Arabic decorations and calligraphy. The principal Islamic architectural types are: the <a href="/wiki/Mosque" title="Mosque">Mosque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Tomb" title="Tomb">Tomb</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Palace" title="Palace">Palace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Fort" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort">Fort</a>. From these four types, the vocabulary of Islamic architecture is derived and used for other buildings such as <a href="/wiki/Public_baths" class="mw-redirect" title="Public baths">public baths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Fountains">fountains</a> and domestic architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-Cop149_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cop149-311">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">Arabic music</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg/220px-Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg" width="220" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg/330px-Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg/440px-Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2024" data-file-height="1841" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Maler_der_Geschichte_von_Bay%C3%A2d_und_Riy%C3%A2d_002.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bayad plays the "Oud to The Lady," from the <i><a href="/wiki/Hadith_Bayad_wa_Riyad" title="Hadith Bayad wa Riyad">Bayad &amp; Riyad</a></i>, Arabic tale</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_music" title="Arabic music">Arabic music</a>, while independent and flourishing in the 2010s, has a long history of interaction with many other regional musical styles and genres. It is an amalgam of the music of the Arab people in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> and the music of all the peoples that make up the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> today<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> Pre-Islamic Arab music was similar to that of Ancient Middle Eastern music. Most historians agree that there existed distinct forms of music in the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian peninsula">Arabian peninsula</a> in the pre-Islamic period between the 5th and 7th century CE. <a href="/wiki/Arabic_poetry" title="Arabic poetry">Arab poets</a> of that "Jahili poets", meaning "the poets of the period of ignorance"—used to recite poems with a high notes.<sup id="cite_ref-Jahili_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahili-314">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> It was believed that <a href="/wiki/Genie" class="mw-redirect" title="Genie">Jinns</a> revealed poems to poets and music to musicians.<sup id="cite_ref-Jahili_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahili-314">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jahili_314-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jahili-314">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> By the 11th century, <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Islamic Iberia</a> had become a center for the manufacture of instruments. These goods spread gradually throughout <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, influencing French <a href="/wiki/Troubadour" title="Troubadour">troubadours</a>, and eventually reaching the rest of <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>. The English words <a href="/wiki/Lute" title="Lute">lute</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rebec" title="Rebec">rebec</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naker</a> are derived from Arabic <a href="/wiki/Oud" title="Oud">oud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rabab" class="mw-redirect" title="Rabab">rabab</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naqareh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Umm_Kulthum4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umm_Kulthum4.jpg/170px-Umm_Kulthum4.jpg" width="170" height="244" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umm_Kulthum4.jpg/255px-Umm_Kulthum4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Umm_Kulthum4.jpg/340px-Umm_Kulthum4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="548" data-file-height="785" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Umm_Kulthum4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Umm_Kulthum" title="Umm Kulthum">Umm Kulthum</a> was an internationally famous Egyptian singer.</div></div></div>
<p>A number of <a href="/wiki/Musical_instrument" title="Musical instrument">musical instruments</a> used in <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a> are believed to have been derived from Arabic musical instruments: the <a href="/wiki/Lute" title="Lute">lute</a> was derived from the <i><a href="/wiki/Oud" title="Oud">Oud</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Rebec" title="Rebec">rebec</a> (ancestor of <a href="/wiki/Violin" title="Violin">violin</a>) from the <i><a href="/wiki/Rebab" title="Rebab">rebab</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Guitar" title="Guitar">guitar</a> from <i>qitara</i>, which in turn was derived from the Persian <a href="/wiki/Tar_(lute)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tar (lute)">Tar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naker</a> from <i><a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naqareh</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Adufe" title="Adufe">adufe</a> from <i><a href="/wiki/Daf" title="Daf">al-duff</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Alboka" title="Alboka">alboka</a> from <i>al-buq</i>, <a href="/wiki/Naffir" class="mw-redirect" title="Naffir">anafil</a> from <i>al-nafir</i>, exabeba from <i>al-shabbaba</i> (<a href="/wiki/Flute" title="Flute">flute</a>), atabal (<a href="/wiki/Bass_drum" title="Bass drum">bass drum</a>) from <i>al-tabl</i>, atambal from <i>al-tinbal</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Balaban_(instrument)" title="Balaban (instrument)">balaban</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Castanet" class="mw-redirect" title="Castanet">castanet</a> from <i>kasatan</i>, <a href="/wiki/Tuna_(music)" title="Tuna (music)">sonajas de azófar</a> from <i>sunuj al-sufr</i>, the <a href="/wiki/Bore_(wind_instruments)" title="Bore (wind instruments)">conical bore</a> <a href="/wiki/Wind_instrument" title="Wind instrument">wind instruments</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> the xelami from the <i>sulami</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Fistula" title="Fistula">fistula</a></i> (flute or <a href="/wiki/Organ_pipe" title="Organ pipe">musical pipe</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup>
the <a href="/wiki/Shawm" title="Shawm">shawm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dulzaina" title="Dulzaina">dulzaina</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Reed_(instrument)" class="mw-redirect" title="Reed (instrument)">reed instruments</a> <i>zamr</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Zurna" title="Zurna">al-zurna</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Galician_gaita" title="Galician gaita">gaita</a> from the <i><a href="/wiki/Rhaita" title="Rhaita">ghaita</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Rackett" title="Rackett">rackett</a> from <i>iraqya</i> or <i>iraqiyya</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Violin" title="Violin">geige</a> (violin) from <i>ghichak</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup>
and the <a href="/wiki/Theorbo" title="Theorbo">theorbo</a> from the <i>tarab</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1950s and the 1960s, Arabic music began to take on a more Western tone – artists <a href="/wiki/Umm_Kulthum" title="Umm Kulthum">Umm Kulthum</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Halim_Hafez" title="Abdel Halim Hafez">Abdel Halim Hafez</a> along with composers <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Abdel_Wahab" title="Mohammed Abdel Wahab">Mohamed Abd al-Wahab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baligh_Hamdi" title="Baligh Hamdi">Baligh Hamdi</a> pioneered the use of western instruments in Egyptian music. By the 1970s several other singers had followed suit and a strand of <a href="/wiki/Arabic_pop" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic pop">Arabic pop</a> was born. Arabic pop usually consists of Western styled songs with Arabic instruments and lyrics. Melodies are often a mix between Eastern and Western. Beginning in the mid-1980s, <a href="/wiki/Lydia_Canaan" title="Lydia Canaan">Lydia Canaan</a>, musical <a href="/wiki/Innovator" class="mw-redirect" title="Innovator">pioneer</a> widely regarded as the first rock star of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a><sup id="cite_ref-Daily_Star_Rock_Hall_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_Star_Rock_Hall-324">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spirituality">Spirituality</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Spirituality">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Al-Uzza.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Al-Uzza.png/220px-Al-Uzza.png" width="220" height="190" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Al-Uzza.png/330px-Al-Uzza.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Al-Uzza.png/440px-Al-Uzza.png 2x" data-file-width="489" data-file-height="422" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Al-Uzza.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Al-%27Uzz%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-&#39;Uzzá">Al-'Uzzá</a> was one of the three chief <a href="/wiki/Goddess" title="Goddess">goddesses</a> of a pagan Arabian religion</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia">Arab polytheism</a> was the dominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Pre-Islamic_Arabia" title="Pre-Islamic Arabia">pre-Islamic Arabia</a>. <a href="/wiki/Deity" title="Deity">Gods</a> and <a href="/wiki/Goddess" title="Goddess">goddesses</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Hubal" title="Hubal">Hubal</a> and the goddesses <a href="/wiki/Al-Lat" title="Al-Lat">al-Lāt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-%27Uzz%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-&#39;Uzzá">Al-'Uzzá</a> and <a href="/wiki/Man%C4%81t" title="Manāt">Manāt</a>, were worshipped at local shrines, such as the <a href="/wiki/Kaaba" title="Kaaba">Kaaba</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>, whilst Arabs in the south, in what is today's Yemen, worshipped various gods, some of which represented the Sun or Moon. Different theories <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_pre-Islamic_Arabia#Mecca" title="Religion in pre-Islamic Arabia">have been proposed</a> regarding the role of <a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allah</a> in Meccan religion.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Robinson_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-332">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Peters_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peters-333">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Peterson2007_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peterson2007-334">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> Many of the physical descriptions of the pre-Islamic gods are traced to <a href="/wiki/Cult_image" title="Cult image">idols</a>, especially near the Kaaba, which is said to have contained up to 360 of them.<sup id="cite_ref-armstrong_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-armstrong-335">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> Until about the fourth century, almost all Arabs practised polytheistic religions.<sup id="cite_ref-Hoyland2002_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hoyland2002-336">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup> Although significant <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish</a> and Christian minorities developed, <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheism</a> remained the dominant belief system in pre-Islamic Arabia.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-57">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Nicolle_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nicolle-337">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The religious beliefs and practices of the nomadic <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">bedouin</a> were distinct from those of the settled tribes of towns such as <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Aslan6_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aslan6-338">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> Nomadic religious belief systems and practices are believed to have included <a href="/wiki/Fetishism" title="Fetishism">fetishism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Totemism" class="mw-redirect" title="Totemism">totemism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_the_dead" title="Veneration of the dead">veneration of the dead</a> but were connected principally with immediate concerns and problems and did not consider larger <a href="/wiki/Philosophy" title="Philosophy">philosophical</a> questions such as the afterlife.<sup id="cite_ref-Aslan6_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aslan6-338">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> Settled urban Arabs, on the other hand, are thought to have believed in a more complex <a href="/wiki/Pantheon_(religion)" title="Pantheon (religion)">pantheon</a> of deities.<sup id="cite_ref-Aslan6_338-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aslan6-338">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> While the Meccans and the other settled inhabitants of the <a href="/wiki/Hejaz" title="Hejaz">Hejaz</a> worshipped their gods at permanent shrines in towns and oases, the bedouin practised their religion on the move.<sup id="cite_ref-Peters105_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peters105-339">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Philosophy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic philosophy">Arabic philosophy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:AverroesColor.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/AverroesColor.jpg/220px-AverroesColor.jpg" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/AverroesColor.jpg/330px-AverroesColor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/AverroesColor.jpg 2x" data-file-width="352" data-file-height="276" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:AverroesColor.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Averroes" title="Averroes">Averroes</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Averroism" title="Averroism">Averroism</a> school of philosophy, was influential in the rise of <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular thought</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Arabi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Ibn_Arabi.jpg/170px-Ibn_Arabi.jpg" width="170" height="218" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e9/Ibn_Arabi.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="218" data-file-height="280" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ibn_Arabi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ibn_Arabi" title="Ibn Arabi">Ibn Arabi</a>, one of the most celebrated mystic-philosophers in Islamic history.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_Philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic Philosophy">Arabic philosophy</a> refers to philosophical thought in the Arab world. Schools of Arabic thought include <a href="/wiki/Avicennism" title="Avicennism">Avicennism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Averroism" title="Averroism">Averroism</a>. The first great Arab thinker is widely regarded to be <a href="/wiki/Al-Kindi" title="Al-Kindi">al-Kindi</a> (801–873 A.D.), a <a href="/wiki/Neo-Platonic" class="mw-redirect" title="Neo-Platonic">Neo-Platonic</a> philosopher, <a href="/wiki/Mathematician" title="Mathematician">mathematician</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scientist" title="Scientist">scientist</a> who lived in <a href="/wiki/Kufa" title="Kufa">Kufa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a> (modern day <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>). After being appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphs" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbasid Caliphs">Abbasid Caliphs</a> to translate <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> scientific and <a href="/wiki/Philosophical" class="mw-redirect" title="Philosophical">philosophical</a> texts into <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>, he wrote a number of original treatises of his own on a range of subjects, from <a href="/wiki/Metaphysics" title="Metaphysics">metaphysics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethic" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethic">ethics</a> to <a href="/wiki/Mathematic" class="mw-redirect" title="Mathematic">mathematics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pharmacology" title="Pharmacology">pharmacology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of his <a href="/wiki/Philosophy" title="Philosophy">philosophical</a> output focuses on <a href="/wiki/Theology" title="Theology">theological</a> subjects such as the nature of <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prophecy" title="Prophecy">prophetic</a> knowledge.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> Doctrines of the Arabic philosophers of the 9th–12th century who influenced medieval <a href="/wiki/Scholasticism" title="Scholasticism">Scholasticism</a> in Europe. The Arabic tradition combines <a href="/wiki/Aristotelianism" title="Aristotelianism">Aristotelianism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neoplatonism" title="Neoplatonism">Neoplatonism</a> with other ideas introduced through <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>. Influential thinkers include the Persians <a href="/wiki/Al-Farabi" title="Al-Farabi">al-Farabi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Avicenna" title="Avicenna">Avicenna</a>. The Arabic philosophic literature was translated into <a href="/wiki/Hebrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Hebrew">Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, this contributed to the development of modern European philosophy. The Arabic tradition was developed by <a href="/wiki/Moses_Maimonides" class="mw-redirect" title="Moses Maimonides">Moses Maimonides</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun" title="Ibn Khaldun">Ibn Khaldun</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science">Science</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Science">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_science" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic science">Arabic science</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia,_title.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg/170px-Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg" width="170" height="276" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg/255px-Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg/340px-Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia%2C_title.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1245" data-file-height="2019" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Houghton_Typ_620.47.452_-_Selenographia,_title.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hevelius" class="mw-redirect" title="Hevelius">Hevelius</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Selenographia" class="mw-redirect" title="Selenographia">Selenographia</a></i>, showing <a href="/wiki/Alhazen" class="mw-redirect" title="Alhazen">Alhazen</a> &#32;&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">sic</a></i>&#93; representing reason, and <a href="/wiki/Galileo_Galilei" title="Galileo Galilei">Galileo</a> representing the senses. Alhazen has been described as the "world's first true scientist".<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Science_in_the_medieval_Islamic_world" title="Science in the medieval Islamic world">Arabic science</a> underwent considerable development during the 8th to 13th centuries CE, a source of knowledge that later spread throughout <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and greatly influenced both medical practice and education. These scientific accomplishments occurred after <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> united the <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">Arab tribes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Albategnius.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Albategnius.jpeg/170px-Albategnius.jpeg" width="170" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Albategnius.jpeg/255px-Albategnius.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Albategnius.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="426" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Albategnius.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Al-Battani" title="Al-Battani">Albategnius</a>'s <i>Kitāb az-Zīj</i> was one of the most influential books in medieval astronomy</div></div></div>
<p>Within a century after Muhammed's death (632 CE), an empire ruled by Arabs was established. It encompassed a large part of the planet, stretching from southern Europe to <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a> to <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> and on to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>. In 711 CE, Arab Muslims invaded southern Spain; <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a> was a center of Arabic scientific accomplishment. Another center emerged in <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasids</a>, who ruled part of the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Islamic world</a> during a historic period later characterized as the "<a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Golden Age</a>" (∼750 to 1258 CE).<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg/170px-TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg" width="170" height="78" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg/255px-TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg/340px-TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg 2x" data-file-width="12992" data-file-height="5952" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:TabulaRogeriana_upside-down.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Tabula_Rogeriana" title="Tabula Rogeriana">Tabula Rogeriana</a>, drawn by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_al-Idrisi" title="Muhammad al-Idrisi">al-Idrisi</a> for <a href="/wiki/Roger_II_of_Sicily" title="Roger II of Sicily">Roger II of Sicily</a> in 1154, is one of the most advanced <a href="/wiki/Ancient_world_maps" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient world maps">ancient world maps</a>. Modern consolidation, created from the 70 double-page spreads of the original atlas.</div></div></div>
<p>This era can be identified as the years between 692 and 945,<sup id="cite_ref-World_Civilization_Vol_1_1974,_pg._234_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Civilization_Vol_1_1974,_pg._234-347">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> and ended when the caliphate was marginalized by local Muslim rulers in Baghdad&#160;– its traditional seat of power. From 945 onward until the <a href="/wiki/Sack_of_Baghdad" class="mw-redirect" title="Sack of Baghdad">sacking of Baghdad</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasions">Mongols</a> in 1258, the Caliph continued on as a figurehead, with power devolving more to local <a href="/wiki/Amir" class="mw-redirect" title="Amir">amirs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Civilization_Vol_1_1974,_pg._233_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Civilization_Vol_1_1974,_pg._233-348">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> The pious scholars of Islam, men and women collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Ulama" title="Ulama">ulama</a>, were the most influential element of society in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> law, speculative thought and theology.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> Arabic scientific achievement is not as yet fully understood, but is very large.<sup id="cite_ref-RobinsonCambridge_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobinsonCambridge-350">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup> These achievements encompass a wide range of subject areas, especially <a href="/wiki/Mathematics_in_medieval_Islam" title="Mathematics in medieval Islam">mathematics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Astronomy_in_medieval_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Astronomy in medieval Islam">astronomy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Medicine_in_medieval_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Medicine in medieval Islam">medicine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-RobinsonCambridge_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobinsonCambridge-350">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup> Other subjects of scientific inquiry included <a href="/wiki/Physics_in_medieval_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Physics in medieval Islam">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alchemy_and_chemistry_in_medieval_Islam" title="Alchemy and chemistry in medieval Islam">alchemy and chemistry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cosmology_in_medieval_Islam" title="Cosmology in medieval Islam">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Islamic_ophthalmology" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval Islamic ophthalmology">ophthalmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geography_and_cartography_in_medieval_Islam" title="Geography and cartography in medieval Islam">geography and cartography</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sociology_in_medieval_Islam" class="mw-redirect" title="Sociology in medieval Islam">sociology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Psychology_in_medieval_Islam" title="Psychology in medieval Islam">psychology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Al-Battani" title="Al-Battani">Al-Battani</a> (c. 858 – 929; born <a href="/wiki/Harran" title="Harran">Harran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bilad_al-Sham" title="Bilad al-Sham">Bilad al-Sham</a>) was an Arab astronomer, astrologer and mathematician of the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a>. His work is considered instrumental in the development of science and astronomy. One of Al-Battani's best-known achievements in astronomy was the determination of the solar year as being 365 days, 5 hours, 46 minutes and 24 seconds which is only 2 minutes and 22 seconds off.<sup id="cite_ref-MacTutor_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacTutor-353">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Haytham" title="Ibn al-Haytham">Ibn al-Haytham</a> (Alhazen) used experimentation to obtain the results in his <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Optics" title="Book of Optics">Book of Optics</a></i> (1021), an important development in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_scientific_method" title="History of scientific method">history of the scientific method</a>. He combined <a href="/wiki/Observation" title="Observation">observations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Experiment" title="Experiment">experiments</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rationality" title="Rationality">rational</a> arguments to support his intromission theory of <a href="/wiki/Visual_perception" title="Visual perception">vision</a>, in which <a href="/wiki/Ray_(optics)" title="Ray (optics)">rays</a> of <a href="/wiki/Light" title="Light">light</a> are emitted from objects rather than from the eyes. He used similar arguments to show that the ancient <a href="/wiki/Emission_theory_(vision)" title="Emission theory (vision)">emission theory of vision</a> supported by <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Euclid" title="Euclid">Euclid</a> (in which the eyes emit the rays of light used for seeing), and the ancient <a href="/wiki/Intromission_theory" class="mw-redirect" title="Intromission theory">intromission theory</a> supported by <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a> (where objects emit physical particles to the eyes), were both wrong.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Al-Zahrawi" title="Al-Zahrawi">Al-Zahrawi</a>, regarded by many as the greatest surgeon of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_ages" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle ages">middle ages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> His surgical treatise "<a href="/wiki/Al-Tasrif" title="Al-Tasrif">De chirurgia</a>" is the first illustrated surgical guide ever written. It remained the primary source for surgical procedures and instruments in Europe for the next 500 years.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> The book helped lay the foundation to establish <a href="/wiki/Surgery" title="Surgery">surgery</a> as a scientific discipline independent from <a href="/wiki/Medicine" title="Medicine">medicine</a>, earning <a href="/wiki/Al-Zahrawi" title="Al-Zahrawi">al-Zahrawi</a> his name as one of the founders of this field.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other notable <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> contributions include among other things: establishing the science of <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a> by <a href="/wiki/J%C4%81bir_ibn_Hayy%C4%81n" class="mw-redirect" title="Jābir ibn Hayyān">Jābir ibn Hayyān</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> establishing the science of <a href="/wiki/Cryptology" class="mw-redirect" title="Cryptology">cryptology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cryptanalysis" title="Cryptanalysis">cryptanalysis</a> by <a href="/wiki/Al-Kindi" title="Al-Kindi">al-Kindi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> the development of <a href="/wiki/Analytic_geometry" title="Analytic geometry">analytic geometry</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Haytham" title="Ibn al-Haytham">Ibn al-Haytham</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_circulation" title="Pulmonary circulation">pulmonary circulation</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Nafis" title="Ibn al-Nafis">Ibn al-Nafis</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/Itch_mite" class="mw-redirect" title="Itch mite">itch mite</a> parasite by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Zuhr" title="Ibn Zuhr">Ibn Zuhr</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup> the first use of <a href="/wiki/Irrational_numbers" class="mw-redirect" title="Irrational numbers">irrational numbers</a> as an algebraic objects by <a href="/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_K%C4%81mil" class="mw-redirect" title="Abū Kāmil">Abū Kāmil</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> the first use of the positional <a href="/wiki/Decimal_fractions" class="mw-redirect" title="Decimal fractions">decimal fractions</a> by <a href="/wiki/Abu%27l-Hasan_al-Uqlidisi" title="Abu&#39;l-Hasan al-Uqlidisi">al-Uqlidisi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> the development of the <a href="/wiki/Arabic_numerals" title="Arabic numerals">Arabic numerals</a> and an early <a href="/wiki/History_of_mathematical_notation" title="History of mathematical notation">algebraic symbolism</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Thabit_number" title="Thabit number">Thabit number</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amicable_numbers#Thābit_ibn_Qurra_theorem" title="Amicable numbers">Thābit theorem</a> by <a href="/wiki/Th%C4%81bit_ibn_Qurra" title="Thābit ibn Qurra">Thābit ibn Qurra</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> the discovery of several new <a href="/wiki/List_of_trigonometric_identities" title="List of trigonometric identities">trigonometric identities</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Yunus" title="Ibn Yunus">Ibn Yunus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Al-Battani" title="Al-Battani">al-Battani</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Mathematical_proof" title="Mathematical proof">mathematical proof</a> for <a href="/wiki/Ceva%27s_theorem" title="Ceva&#39;s theorem">Ceva's theorem</a> by <a href="/wiki/Yusuf_al-Mu%27taman_ibn_Hud" title="Yusuf al-Mu&#39;taman ibn Hud">Ibn Hűd</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> the first accurate <a href="/wiki/Lunar_theory" title="Lunar theory">lunar model</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Shatir" title="Ibn al-Shatir">Ibn al-Shatir</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> the invention of the <a href="/wiki/Torquetum" title="Torquetum">torquetum</a> by <a href="/wiki/Jabir_ibn_Aflah" title="Jabir ibn Aflah">Jabir ibn Aflah</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> the invention of the universal <a href="/wiki/Astrolabe" title="Astrolabe">astrolabe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Equatorium" title="Equatorium">equatorium</a> by <a href="/wiki/Al-Zarqali" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Zarqali">al-Zarqali</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> the first description of the <a href="/wiki/Crankshaft" title="Crankshaft">crankshaft</a> by <a href="/wiki/Al-Jazari" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Jazari">al-Jazari</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> the anticipation of the <a href="/wiki/Inertia" title="Inertia">inertia</a> concept by <a href="/wiki/Averroes" title="Averroes">Averroes</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> the discovery of the <a href="/wiki/Reaction_(physics)" title="Reaction (physics)">physical reaction</a> by <a href="/wiki/Avempace" title="Avempace">Avempace</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> the identification of more than 200 new <a href="/wiki/Plants" class="mw-redirect" title="Plants">plants</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Baitar" title="Ibn al-Baitar">Ibn al-Baitar</a><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Agricultural_Revolution" title="Arab Agricultural Revolution">Arab Agricultural Revolution</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Tabula_Rogeriana" title="Tabula Rogeriana">Tabula Rogeriana</a>, which was the most accurate world map in pre-modern times by <a href="/wiki/Al-Idrisi" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Idrisi">al-Idrisi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bacharach_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bacharach-387">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The birth of the University institution can be traced to this development, as several universities and educational institutions of the Arab world such as the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Al_Quaraouiyine" title="University of Al Quaraouiyine">University of Al Quaraouiyine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Azhar_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Azhar University">Al Azhar University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ez-Zitouna" title="University of Ez-Zitouna">Al Zaytuna University</a> are considered to be the oldest in the world. Founded by <a href="/wiki/Fatima_al-Fihri" title="Fatima al-Fihri">Fatima al Fihri</a> in 859, the University of Al Quaraouiyine in <a href="/wiki/Fez" title="Fez">Fez</a> is the oldest existing, continually operating and the first <a href="/wiki/Academic_degree" title="Academic degree">degree</a> awarding educational institution in the world according to <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" title="Guinness World Records">Guinness World Records</a><sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> and is sometimes referred to as the oldest university.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many scientific <a href="/wiki/Influence_of_Arabic_on_other_languages" title="Influence of Arabic on other languages">Arabic loanwords</a> in Western European languages, including <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Category:English_terms_derived_from_Arabic" class="extiw" title="wikt:Category:English terms derived from Arabic">English</a>, mostly via Old French.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> This includes <a href="/wiki/List_of_Arabic_star_names" title="List of Arabic star names">traditional star names</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Aldebaran" title="Aldebaran">Aldebaran</a>, scientific terms like <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/alchemy" class="extiw" title="wikt:alchemy">alchemy</a></i> (whence also <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/chemistry" class="extiw" title="wikt:chemistry">chemistry</a></i>), <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/algebra" class="extiw" title="wikt:algebra">algebra</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/algorithm" class="extiw" title="wikt:algorithm">algorithm</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/alcohol" class="extiw" title="wikt:alcohol">alcohol</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/alkali" class="extiw" title="wikt:alkali">alkali</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/cipher" class="extiw" title="wikt:cipher">cipher</a></i>, <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/zenith" class="extiw" title="wikt:zenith">zenith</a></i>, etc.
</p><p>Under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_rule" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman rule">Ottoman rule</a>, cultural life and science in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> declined. In the 20th and 21st centuries, Arabs who have won important science prizes include <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Zewail" title="Ahmed Zewail">Ahmed Zewail</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elias_Corey" class="mw-redirect" title="Elias Corey">Elias Corey</a> (<a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prize</a>), <a href="/wiki/Michael_DeBakey" title="Michael DeBakey">Michael DeBakey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alim_Louis_Benabid" title="Alim Louis Benabid">Alim Benabid</a> (<a href="/wiki/Lasker_Award" title="Lasker Award">Lasker Award</a>), <a href="/wiki/Omar_M._Yaghi" title="Omar M. Yaghi">Omar M. Yaghi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Wolf_Prize" title="Wolf Prize">Wolf Prize</a>), <a href="/wiki/Huda_Zoghbi" title="Huda Zoghbi">Huda Zoghbi</a> (<a href="/wiki/Shaw_Prize" title="Shaw Prize">Shaw Prize</a>), <a href="/wiki/Zaha_Hadid" title="Zaha Hadid">Zaha Hadid</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pritzker_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="Pritzker Prize">Pritzker Prize</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Atiyah" title="Michael Atiyah">Michael Atiyah</a> both (<a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>) and (<a href="/wiki/Abel_Prize" title="Abel Prize">Abel Prize</a>). <a href="/wiki/Rachid_Yazami" title="Rachid Yazami">Rachid Yazami</a> was one of the co-inventors of the <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery" title="Lithium-ion battery">lithium-ion battery</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tony_Fadell" title="Tony Fadell">Tony Fadell</a> was important in the development of the <a href="/wiki/IPod" title="IPod">iPod</a> and the <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">iPhone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wedding_and_marriage">Wedding and marriage</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Wedding and marriage">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Arabic_wedding" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic wedding">Arabic wedding</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9,_Maroc.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg/220px-Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg/330px-Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg/440px-Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9%2C_Maroc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tatouage_au_Henn%C3%A9,_Maroc.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Henna" title="Henna">Henna</a> tattoo in <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Arabic_wedding" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic wedding">Arabic weddings</a> have changed greatly in the past 100 years. Original traditional Arabic weddings are supposed to be very similar to modern-day <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouin</a> weddings and rural weddings, and they are in some cases unique from one region to another, even within the same <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">country</a>. The practice of <a href="/wiki/Marriage" title="Marriage">marrying</a> of relatives is a common feature of <a href="/wiki/Arab_culture" title="Arab culture">Arab culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> today between 40% and 50% of all marriages are <a href="/wiki/Consanguineous" class="mw-redirect" title="Consanguineous">consanguineous</a> or between close family members, though these figures may vary among Arab nations.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pmid24294299_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid24294299-396">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, around 40% of the population <a href="/wiki/Cousin_marriage" title="Cousin marriage">marry a cousin</a>. A 1992 survey in <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> found that 32% were married to a first cousin; a further 17.3% were married to more distant relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> 67% of marriages in <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> are between close relatives as are 54% of all marriages in <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, whereas 18% of all <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanese</a> were between <a href="/wiki/Blood" title="Blood">blood</a> relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-Inbreeding_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inbreeding-398">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Inbreeding_398-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inbreeding-398">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> Due to the actions of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rightly_Guided_Caliphs" class="mw-redirect" title="Rightly Guided Caliphs">Rightly Guided Caliphs</a>, marriage between cousins is explicitly allowed in <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Qur'an</a> itself does not discourage or forbid the practice.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, opinions vary on whether the <a href="/wiki/Phenomenon" title="Phenomenon">phenomenon</a> should be seen as exclusively based on Islamic practices as a 1992 study among Arabs in Jordan did not show significant differences between <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Christian Arabs</a> or <a href="/wiki/Arab_Muslims" title="Arab Muslims">Muslim Arabs</a> when comparing the occurrence of <a href="/wiki/Consanguinity" title="Consanguinity">consanguinity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Inbreeding_398-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Inbreeding-398">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetics">Genetics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Genetics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_studies_on_Arabs" title="Genetic studies on Arabs">Genetic studies on Arabs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Y-DNA_haplogroups_in_populations_of_the_Near_East" title="Y-DNA haplogroups in populations of the Near East">Y-DNA haplogroups in populations of the Near East</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Y-DNA_haplogroups_in_populations_of_North_Africa" title="Y-DNA haplogroups in populations of North Africa">Y-DNA haplogroups in populations of North Africa</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> is the most frequent paternal clade among the populations in the western part of the Arab world (Maghreb, Nile Valley, and the Horn of Africa), whereas haplogroup <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267" title="Haplogroup J-M267">J</a> is the most frequent paternal clade toward the east (Arabian peninsula and Near East). Other less common haplogroups are <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1a_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R1a (Y-DNA)">R1a</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R1b (Y-DNA)">R1b</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup G (Y-DNA)">G</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup I (Y-DNA)">I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_L-M20" title="Haplogroup L-M20">L</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup T (Y-DNA)">T</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Al-Zahery_288_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Al-Zahery_288-400">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cerny2009_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cerny2009-404">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:484px;max-width:484px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:172px;max-width:172px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Haplogroup_J_(Y-DNA).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg/170px-Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg.png" width="170" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg/255px-Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg/340px-Haplogroup_J_%28Y-DNA%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="680" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M304" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup J-M304">J-M304</a></div></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:192px;max-width:192px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:HG_J1_(ADN-Y).PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG/190px-HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG" width="190" height="127" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG/285px-HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG/380px-HG_J1_%28ADN-Y%29.PNG 2x" data-file-width="613" data-file-height="411" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267" title="Haplogroup J-M267">J-M267</a></div></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:114px;max-width:114px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:E1b1bRoute.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/E1b1bRoute.png/112px-E1b1bRoute.png" width="112" height="126" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/E1b1bRoute.png/168px-E1b1bRoute.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/E1b1bRoute.png/224px-E1b1bRoute.png 2x" data-file-width="324" data-file-height="364" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E-M215</a></div></div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>
<p>Listed here are the <a href="/wiki/Human_Y-chromosome_DNA_haplogroups" class="mw-redirect" title="Human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroups">human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroups</a> in Arabian Peninsula, <a href="/wiki/Mashriq" title="Mashriq">Mashriq</a> or <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> Valley.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cinnioglu_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cinnioglu-415">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Haber2013_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haber2013-418">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Yemenis" class="mw-redirect" title="Yemenis">Yemeni Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup J-M267 (Y-DNA)">J</a> (82.3%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (12.9%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V38" title="Haplogroup E-V38">E1b1a</a> (3.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-Cadenas2008_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cadenas2008-420">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Saudis" title="Saudis">Saudi Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup J-M267 (Y-DNA)">J1</a> (58%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V38" title="Haplogroup E-V38">E1b1b</a> (7.6%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V38" title="Haplogroup E-V38">E1b1a</a> (7.6%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1a1" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R1a1">R1a</a> (5.1%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T-M184" title="Haplogroup T-M184">T</a> (5.1%), G (3.2%) and L (1.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Emiratis" title="Emiratis">Emirati Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup J-M267 (Y-DNA)">J</a> (45.1%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (11.6%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1a1" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R1a1">R1a</a> (7.3%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V38" title="Haplogroup E-V38">E1b1a</a> (5.5%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T-M184" title="Haplogroup T-M184">T</a> (4.9%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b" title="Haplogroup R1b">R1b</a> (4.3%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_L-M20" title="Haplogroup L-M20">L</a> (3%).<sup id="cite_ref-Cadenas2008_420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cadenas2008-420">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Omanis" title="Omanis">Omani Arabs</a> J (47.9%), E1b1b (15.7%), R1a (9.1%), T (8.3%), E1b1a (7.4%), R1b (1.7%), G (1.7%) and L (0.8%).<sup id="cite_ref-Luis2004_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Luis2004-424">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Qatari" class="mw-redirect" title="Qatari">Qatari Arabs</a> J (66.7%), R1a (6.9%), E1b1b (5.6%), E1b1a (2.8%), G (2.8%) and L (2.8%).<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese Arabs</a> J (45.2%), E1b1b (25.8%), R1a (9.7%), R1b (6.4%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G-M201" title="Haplogroup G-M201">G</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I-M170" title="Haplogroup I-M170">I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_L-M20" title="Haplogroup L-M20">I</a> (3.2%), (3.2%), (3.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-Semino2000_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Semino2000-427">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Syrians" title="Syrians">Syrian Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-P209" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup J-P209">J</a> (58.3%),<sup id="cite_ref-Contrasts_in_Affinities_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Contrasts_in_Affinities-428">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-coastal-inland_contrast_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coastal-inland_contrast-429">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (12.0%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I-M170" title="Haplogroup I-M170">I</a> (5.0%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R-M420" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R-M420">R1a</a> (10.0%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R1b (Y-DNA)">R1b</a> 15.0%.<sup id="cite_ref-Semino2000_427-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Semino2000-427">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-coastal-inland_contrast_429-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coastal-inland_contrast-429">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinian Arabs</a> J (55.2%), E1b1b (20.3%), R1b (8.4%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I-M170" title="Haplogroup I-M170">I</a> (6.3%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G-M201" title="Haplogroup G-M201">G</a> (7%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R-M420" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R-M420">R1a</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T-M184" title="Haplogroup T-M184">T</a> (1.4%), (1.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-Nebel2001_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nebel2001-430">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Coffman_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coffman-431">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Jordan" title="Demographics of Jordan">Jordanian Arabs</a> J (43.8%), E1b1b (26%), R1b (17.8%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G-M201" title="Haplogroup G-M201">G</a> (4.1%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I-M170" title="Haplogroup I-M170">I</a> (3.4%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R-M420" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup R-M420">R1a</a> (1.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iraqis" title="Iraqis">Iraqi Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup J (mtDNA)">J</a> (50.6%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (10.8%), R1b (10.8%), R1a (6.9%) and T (5.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-Semino2004_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Semino2004-433">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Zahery_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zahery-434">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptian Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E1b1b" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup E1b1b">E1b1b</a> (36.7%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)">J</a> (32%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup G (Y-DNA)">G</a> (8.8%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup T (Y-DNA)">T</a> (8.2% <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b" title="Haplogroup R1b">R1b</a> (4.1%), <a href="/wiki/E1b1a" class="mw-redirect" title="E1b1a">E1b1a</a> (2.8%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup I (Y-DNA)">I</a> (0.7%).<sup id="cite_ref-Cinnioglu_415-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cinnioglu-415">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wood2005_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wood2005-435">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sudanese_Arabs" title="Sudanese Arabs">Sudanese Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)">J</a> (47.1%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E1b1b" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup E1b1b">E1b1b</a> (16.3%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b" title="Haplogroup R1b">R1b</a> (15.7%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_I_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup I (Y-DNA)">I</a> (3.13%).<sup id="cite_ref-Hassan_2008_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassan_2008-436">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hassan_316–23_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hassan_316–23-437">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Moroccans" title="Moroccans">Moroccan Arabs</a> E1b1b (75.5%) and J1 (20.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-Haplogroup_E3b_2004_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haplogroup_E3b_2004-438">&#91;436&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Eurasia_2016_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurasia_2016-439">&#91;437&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tunisian_people" title="Tunisian people">Tunisian Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (49.3%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267" title="Haplogroup J-M267">J1</a> (35.8%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b" title="Haplogroup R1b">R1b</a> (6.8%) and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-V38" title="Haplogroup E-V38">E1b1a</a> (1.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-Arredi2004_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arredi2004-440">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Algeria" title="Algeria">Algerian Arabs</a> <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_E-M215_(Y-DNA)" title="Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)">E1b1b</a> (54%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J-M267" title="Haplogroup J-M267">J1</a> (35%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R1b" title="Haplogroup R1b">R1b</a> (13%).<sup id="cite_ref-Arredi2004_440-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arredi2004-440">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libyan Arabs</a> E1b1b (35.88%), J (30.53%), E1b1a (8.78%), <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_G_(Y-DNA)" class="mw-redirect" title="Haplogroup G (Y-DNA)">G</a> (4.20%), R1a/R1b (3.43%) and E (1.53%).<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">&#91;439&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Immel2006_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Immel2006-442">&#91;440&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The mtDNA <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_J_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup J (mtDNA)">haplogroup J</a> has been observed at notable frequencies among overall populations in the Arab world.<sup id="cite_ref-Elsevier_Inc_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elsevier_Inc-443">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">&#91;442&#93;</a></sup> The maternal clade <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_R0_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup R0 (mtDNA)">R0</a> reaches its highest frequency in the Arabian peninsula,<sup id="cite_ref-Non_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Non-445">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_K_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup K (mtDNA)">K</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_T_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup T (mtDNA)">T</a>(specifically subclade T2) is more common in the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Elsevier_Inc_443-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elsevier_Inc-443">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup> In the Nile Valley and Horn of Africa, haplogroups <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_N_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup N (mtDNA)">N1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_M_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup M (mtDNA)">M1</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-Non_445-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Non-445">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup> in the Maghreb, haplogroups <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_H_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup H (mtDNA)">H1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haplogroup_U_(mtDNA)" title="Haplogroup U (mtDNA)">U6</a> are more significant.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">&#91;444&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are four principal West Eurasian autosomal DNA components that characterize the populations in the Arab world: the Arabian, Levantine, Coptic and Maghrebi components.
</p><p>The Arabian component is the main autosomal element in the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> region.
