It is most closely associated with local Arabic-speaking populations.<sup id="cite_ref-Haber2013_418-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haber2013-418">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup> The Arabian component is also found at significant frequencies in parts of the Levant and Northeast Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-Haber2013_418-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haber2013-418">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Henn2012_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henn2012-447">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup> The geographical distribution pattern of this component correlates with the pattern of the Islamic expansion, but its presence in Lebanese Christians, Sephardi and Ashkenazi Jews, Cypriots and Armenians might suggest that its spread to the Levant could also represent an earlier event.<sup id="cite_ref-Haber2013_418-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haber2013-418">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Levantine component is the main autosomal element in the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>. It peaks among <a href="/wiki/Druze_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Druze people">Druze</a> populations in the Levant. The Levantine component diverged from the Arabian component about 15,500–23,700 ypb.<sup id="cite_ref-Haber2013_418-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Haber2013-418">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Coptic component is the main autosomal element in <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="Northeast Africa">Northeast Africa</a>. It peaks among <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptian</a> <a href="/wiki/Copts" title="Copts">Copts</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a>, and is also found at high frequencies among other Afro-Asiatic-speaking populations in the <a href="/wiki/Nile_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Nile Valley">Nile Valley</a> and the Horn of Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-Dobon2015_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dobon2015-448">&#91;446&#93;</a></sup>The Coptic component is roughly equivalent with the Ethio-Somali component.<sup id="cite_ref-Hodgson2014_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hodgson2014-449">&#91;447&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Maghrebi component is the main autosomal element in the Maghreb. It peaks among the non-Arabized <a href="/wiki/Berbers" title="Berbers">Berber</a> populations in the region.<sup id="cite_ref-Henn2012_447-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henn2012-447">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup> The Maghrebi component diverged from the Coptic/Ethio-Somali, Arabian and Levantine components prior to the <a href="/wiki/Holocene" title="Holocene">Holocene</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Henn2012_447-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Henn2012-447">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hodgson2014_449-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hodgson2014-449">&#91;447&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.brazzil.com/2004/html/articles/sep04/p118sep04.htm">"Arabs Love Brazil. <li id="cite_note-aurora-israel.co.il-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-aurora-israel.co.il_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="languageicon">(in Spanish)</span> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100610201209/http://www.aurora-israel.co.il/articulos/israel/Titulares/24782/">En Chile viven unas 700.000 personas de origen árabe y de ellas 500.000 son descendientes de emigrantes palestinos que llegaron a comienzos del siglo pasado y que constituyen la comunidad de ese origen más grande fuera del mundo árabe.</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ISTAT-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ISTAT_25-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ISTAT_25-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Dati ISTAT 2016, counting only immigrants from the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tuttitalia.it/statistiche/cittadini-stranieri-2016/">"Cittadini stranieri in Italia – 2016"</a>. <i>tuttitalia.it</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=tuttitalia.it&amp;rft.atitle=Cittadini+stranieri+in+Italia+%E2%80%93+2016&amp;rft.aulast=Dati+ISTAT+2016&amp;rft.aufirst=counting+only+immigrants+from+the+Arab+world&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tuttitalia.it%2Fstatistiche%2Fcittadini-stranieri-2016%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-Abraham_2010-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Abraham_2010_36-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Atzmon, G; Hao, <li id="cite_note-Tadmouri2014-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Tadmouri2014_37-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Ghazi O. Tadmouri; Konduru S. Sastry; Lotfi Chouchane (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4355514">"Arab gene geography: From population diversities to personalized medical genomics"</a>. <i>Global Cardiology Science and Practice</i>. <b>2014</b> (4): 394–408. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.5339%2Fgcsp.2014.54">10.5339/gcsp.2014.54</a>. <a href="/wiki/PubMed_Central" title="PubMed Central">PMC</a>&#160;<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4355514">4355514</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" class="mw-redirect" title="PubMed Identifier">PMID</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25780794">25780794</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Global+Cardiology+Science+and+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Arab+gene+geography%3A+From+population+diversities+to+personalized+medical+genomics&amp;rft.volume=2014&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=394-408&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4355514&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F25780794&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.5339%2Fgcsp.2014.54&amp;rft.au=Ghazi+O.+Tadmouri&amp;rft.au=Konduru+S.+Sastry&amp;rft.au=Lotfi+Chouchane&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4355514&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Serge D. Elie, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://cy.revues.org/document186.html">"Hadiboh: From Peripheral Village to Emerging City"</a>, <i>Chroniques Yéménites</i>: "In the middle, were the Arabs who originated from different parts of the mainland (e.g., prominent Mahrî tribes10, and individuals from Hadramawt, and Aden)". Footnote 10: "Their neighbors in the West scarcely regarded them as Arabs, though they themselves consider they are of the pure stock of Himyar."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Arabs">"Arabs - Wiktionary"</a>. <i>en.wiktionary.org</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=en.wiktionary.org&amp;rft.atitle=Arabs+-+Wiktionary&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fen.wiktionary.org%2Fwiki%2FArabs&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>
</li>

</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-EoR-Ishmael-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-EoR-Ishmael_45-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Fredrick E. Greenspahn (2005). "Ishmael".  In Lindsay Jones. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0jMOAQAAMAAJ&amp;dq=Ishmael"><i>Encyclopedia of Religion</i></a>. <b>7</b>. Macmillan Reference USA. pp.&#160;4551–4552. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780028657400" title="Special:BookSources/9780028657400">9780028657400</a>. <q>ISHMAEL, or, in Hebrew, Yishmaʿeʾl; eldest son of Abraham. Ishmael's mother was Hagar, an Egyptian slave girl whom Sarah gave to Abraham because of her own infertility; in accordance with Mesopotamian law, the offspring of such a union would be credited to Sarah (Gn. 16:2). The name Yishmaʿeʾl is known from various ancient Semitic cultures and means "God has hearkened," suggesting that a child so named was regarded as the fulfillment of a divine promise. Ishmael was circumcised at the age of thirteen by Abraham and expelled with his mother at the instigation of Sarah, who wanted to ensure that Isaac would be Abraham's heir (Gn. 21). In the New Testament, Paul uses this incident to symbolize the relationship between Judaism, the older but now rejected tradition, and Christianity (Gal. 4:21–31). In the Genesis account, God blessed Ishmael, promising that he would be the founder of a great nation and a "wild ass of a man" always at odds with others (Gn. 16:12). He is credited with twelve sons, described as "princes according to their tribes" (Gn. 25:16), representing perhaps an ancient confederacy. The Ishmaelites, vagrant traders closely related to the <a href="/wiki/Midian" title="Midian">Midianites</a>, were apparently regarded as his descendants. The fact that Ishmael's wife and mother are both said to have been Egyptian suggests close ties between the Ishmaelites and Egypt. According to Genesis 25:17, Ishmael lived to the age of 137. Islamic tradition tends to ascribe a larger role to Ishmael than does the Bible. He is considered a prophet and, according to certain theologians, the offspring whom Abraham was commanded to sacrifice (although surah Judaism has generally regarded him as wicked, although repentance is also ascribed to him. According to some rabbinic traditions, his two wives were Aisha and Fatima, whose names are the same as those of Muhammad's wife and daughter Both Judaism and Islam see him as the ancestor of Arab peoples. Bibliography A survey of the Bible's patriarchal narratives can be found in Nahum M. Sarna's Understanding Genesis (New York, 1966). Postbiblical traditions, with reference to Christian and Islamic views, are collected in Louis Ginzberg's exhaustive Legends of the Jews, 2d ed., 2 vols., translated by Henrietta Szold and Paul Radin (Philadelphia, 2003). Frederick E. Greenspahn (1987 and 2005)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Ishmael&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Religion&amp;rft.pages=4551-4552&amp;rft.pub=Macmillan+Reference+USA&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=9780028657400&amp;rft.au=Fredrick+E.+Greenspahn&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D0jMOAQAAMAAJ%26dq%3DIshmael&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/>
<ul><li><cite class="citation book">Noegel, Scott B.; Wheeler, Brannon M. (2010-04-01). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lNAWAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA130&amp;lpg=#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>The A to Z of Prophets in Islam and Judaism</i></a>. Scarecrow Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781461718956" title="Special:BookSources/9781461718956">9781461718956</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+A+to+Z+of+Prophets+in+Islam+and+Judaism&amp;rft.pub=Scarecrow+Press&amp;rft.date=2010-04-01&amp;rft.isbn=9781461718956&amp;rft.aulast=Noegel&amp;rft.aufirst=Scott+B.&amp;rft.au=Wheeler%2C+Brannon+M.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DlNAWAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA130%26lpg%3D%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.therefinersfire.org/ishmael_and_isaac.htm">"Ishmael and Isaac"</a>. <i>Therefinersfire.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Therefinersfire.org&amp;rft.atitle=Ishmael+and+Isaac&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.therefinersfire.org%2Fishmael_and_isaac.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Inc, Encyclopædia Britannica (2012-01-01). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=CeObAAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA156&amp;lpg=PA156&amp;dq=#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Britannica Student Encyclopedia (A-Z Set)</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

<li><cite class="citation book">Grant, Christina Phelps (2003). <i>The Syrian desert&#160;: caravans, travel and exploration</i>. <li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
<ul><li><cite class="citation book">Ruthven, Albert Hourani&#160;; with a new afterword by Malise (2010). <i>A history of the Arab peoples</i> (1st Harvard Press pbk. ed.). Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0674058194" title="Special:BookSources/978-0674058194">978-0674058194</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+history+of+the+Arab+peoples&amp;rft.place=Cambridge%2C+Mass.&amp;rft.edition=1st+Harvard+Press+pbk.&amp;rft.pub=Belknap+Press+of+Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0674058194&amp;rft.aulast=Ruthven&amp;rft.aufirst=Albert+Hourani+%3B+with+a+new+afterword+by+Malise&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?ParagraphID=bbv">"HISTORY OF MIGRATION"</a>. <i>Historyworld.net</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Historyworld.net&amp;rft.atitle=HISTORY+OF+MIGRATION&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.historyworld.net%2Fwrldhis%2FPlainTextHistories.asp%3FParagraphID%3Dbbv&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160903042434/http://people.umass.edu/educ613/WorldhistoryI/WHI.3.html">"Untitled Document"</a>. <i>people.umass.edu</i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://people.umass.edu/educ613/WorldhistoryI/WHI.3.html">the original</a> on 3 September 2016.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=people.umass.edu&amp;rft.atitle=Untitled+Document&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fpeople.umass.edu%2Feduc613%2FWorldhistoryI%2FWHI.3.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.historyworld.net/wrldhis/PlainTextHistories.asp?ParagraphID=ebh">"History of the Arabs (book)"</a>. <i>Historyworld.net</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Historyworld.net&amp;rft.atitle=History+of+the+Arabs+%28book%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.historyworld.net%2Fwrldhis%2FPlainTextHistories.asp%3FParagraphID%3Debh&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation book">Bernard Ellis Lewis, Buntzie Ellis Churchill (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.google.com/books?id=IVyMAvW9slYC&amp;pg=PA137#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Islam: The Religion and the People</i></a>. Pearson Prentice Hall. p.&#160;137<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 August</span> 2017</span>. <q>At the time of the Prophet's birth and mission, the Arabic language was more or less confined to Arabia, a land of deserts, sprinkled with oases. Surrounding it on land on every side were the two rival empires of Persia and Byzantium. The countries of what now make up the Arab world were divided between the two of them—Iraq under Persian rule, Syria, Palestine, and North Africa part of the Byzantine Empire. They spoke a variety of different languages and were for the most part Christians, with some Jewish minorities. Their Arabization and Islamization took place with the vast expansion of Islam in the decades and centuries following the death of the Prophet in 632 CE. The Aramaic language, once dominant in the Fertile Crescent, survives in only a few remote villages and in the rituals of the Eastern churches. Coptic, the language of Christian Egypt before the Arab conquest, has been entirely replaced by Arabic except in the church liturgy. Some earlier languages have survived, notably Kurdish in Southwest Asia and Berber in North Africa, but Arabic, in one form or another, has in effect become the language of everyday speech as well as of government, commerce, and culture in what has come to be known as "the Arab world."</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Islam%3A+The+Religion+and+the+People&amp;rft.pages=137&amp;rft.pub=Pearson+Prentice+Hall&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DIVyMAvW9slYC%26pg%3DPA137%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><span class="citation-comment" style="display:none; color:#33aa33; margin-left:0.3em">CS1 maint: Uses authors parameter (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Uses_authors_parameter" title="Category:CS1 maint: Uses authors parameter">link</a>) </span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li></ul>
</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-56"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-56">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

<li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://uqu.edu.sa/page/ar/56829">The meaning of Arab land in the historical sources </a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100315055238/http://www.uqu.edu.sa/page/ar/56829">Archived</a> 15 March 2010 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cite_quran&#124;34&#124;15&#124;e=17&#124;s=ns-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cite_quran|34|15|e=17|s=ns_70-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D34%3Averse%3D15">34:15–17</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Sheba-01-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Sheba-01_71-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.historyfiles.co.uk/KingListsMiddEast/ArabicSaba.htm">"Saba / Sa'abia / Sheba"</a>. The History Files (<a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.historyfiles.co.uk">http://www.historyfiles.co.uk</a>)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2008-06-27</span></span>. <q>The kingdom of Saba is known to have existed in the region of Yemen. By 1000 BC caravan trains of camels journeyed from Oman in south-east Arabia to the Mediterranean. As the <a href="/wiki/Camel_driver" class="mw-redirect" title="Camel driver">camel drivers</a> passed through the <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">deserts</a> of Yemen, experts believe that many of them would have called in at Ma'rib. Dating from at least 1050 BC, and now barren and dry, <a href="/wiki/Ma%27rib" title="Ma&#39;rib">Ma'rib</a> was then a lush <a href="/wiki/Oasis" title="Oasis">oasis</a> teeming with <a href="/wiki/Palm_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="Palm tree">palm trees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Introduced_species" title="Introduced species">exotic</a> <a href="/wiki/Plant" title="Plant">plants</a>. Ideally placed, it was situated on the trade routes and with a unique <a href="/wiki/Dam" title="Dam">dam</a> of vast proportions. It was also one of only two main sources of <a href="/wiki/Frankincense" title="Frankincense">frankincense</a> (the other being <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>), so Saba had a virtual <a href="/wiki/Monopoly" title="Monopoly">monopoly</a>. Ma'rib's <a href="/wiki/Wealth" title="Wealth">wealth</a> accumulated to such an extent that the city became a byword for riches beyond belief throughout the Arab world. Its people, the <a href="/wiki/Sabeans" class="mw-redirect" title="Sabeans">Sabeans</a> - a group whose name bears the same etymological root as Saba - lived in <a href="/wiki/South_Arabia" title="South Arabia">South Arabia</a> between the tenth and sixth centuries BC. Their main temple - <a href="/wiki/Mahram_Bilqis" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahram Bilqis">Mahram Bilqis</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Temple" title="Temple">temple</a> of the moon god (situated about three miles (5 km) from the capital city of Ma'rib) - was so famous that it remained <a href="/wiki/Sacred" title="Sacred">sacred</a> even after the collapse of the Sabean civilisation in the sixth century BC - caused by the rerouting of the <a href="/wiki/Spice" title="Spice">spice</a> trail. By that point the dam, now in a poor state of repair, was finally breached. The <a href="/wiki/Irrigation" title="Irrigation">irrigation</a> system was lost, the people abandoned the site within a year or so, and the temple fell into disrepair and was eventually covered by sand. Saba was known by the <a href="/wiki/Hebrews" title="Hebrews">Hebrews</a> as Sheba <i>[Note that the collapse of the dam was actually in 575 <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>, as shown in the timeline in the same article in the History Files, and attested by MacCulloch (2009)].</i></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Saba+%2F+Sa%27abia+%2F+Sheba&amp;rft.pub=The+History+Files+%28http%3A%2F%2Fwww.historyfiles.co.uk%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.historyfiles.co.uk%2FKingListsMiddEast%2FArabicSaba.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-72">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
<ul><li>Both Judaism and Islam see him as the ancestor of Arab peoples. <cite class="citation book">Jones, Lindsay (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=0jMOAQAAMAAJ&amp;dq=Ishmael"><i>Encyclopedia of religion</i></a>. Macmillan Reference USA. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780028657400" title="Special:BookSources/9780028657400">9780028657400</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+religion&amp;rft.pub=Macmillan+Reference+USA&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=9780028657400&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Lindsay&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3D0jMOAQAAMAAJ%26dq%3DIshmael&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li>Ishmael is recognized by Muslims as the ancestor of several prominent <a href="/wiki/Arab" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab">Arab</a> <a href="/wiki/Tribes_of_Arabia" title="Tribes of Arabia">tribes</a> and being the forefather of Muhammad. A–Z of Prophets in Islam and Judaism<i>, Wheeler, </i>Ishmael<i> Muslims also believe that Muhammad was the descendant of Ishmael that would establish a great nation, as promised by <a href="/wiki/God_in_Abrahamic_religions" title="God in Abrahamic religions">God</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a>.*<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0117.htm#20">Genesis 17:20</a><cite class="citation book">Zeep, Ira G. (2000). </cite></i>A Muslim primer: beginner's guide to Islam, Volume 2<i>. University of Arkansas Press. p.&#160;5. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-55728-595-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-55728-595-9">978-1-55728-595-9</a>.<span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Muslim+primer%3A+beginner%27s+guide+to+Islam%2C+Volume+2&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Arkansas+Press&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-55728-595-9&amp;rft.aulast=Zeep&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira+G.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></i></li>
<li>Ishmael was considered the ancestor of the Northern Arabs and Muhammad was linked to him through the lineage of the patriarch Adnan. Ishmael may also have been the ancestor of the Southern Arabs through his descendant Qahtan.</li>
<li>"<a href="/wiki/Zayd_ibn_Amr" title="Zayd ibn Amr">Zayd ibn Amr</a>" was another Pre-Islamic figure who refused <a href="/wiki/Idolatry" title="Idolatry">idolatry</a> and preached <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>, claiming it was the original belief of their [Arabs] father Ishmael. *<a href="/wiki/Al-Bidaya_wa%27l-Nihaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Bidaya wa&#39;l-Nihaya">The Beginning and the End</a> by <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Kathir" title="Ibn Kathir">Ibn Kathir</a> – Vol. 3, p. 323 The History by Ibn Khaldun, Vol, 2, p. 4</li>
<li>The tribes of Central West Arabia called themselves the "people of Abraham and the offspring of Ishmael". The Signs of Prophethood, Section 18, page 215.<cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.islamreligion.com/articles/10302/signs-of-prophethood-in-noble-life-of-prophet-muhammad-part-1/">"Signs of Prophethood in the Noble Life of Prophet Muhammad (part 1 of 2): Prophet Muhammad's Early Life – The Religion of Islam"</a>. <i>Islamreligion.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 December</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Islamreligion.com&amp;rft.atitle=Signs+of+Prophethood+in+the+Noble+Life+of+Prophet+Muhammad+%28part+1+of+2%29%3A+Prophet+Muhammad%27s+Early+Life+%E2%80%93+The+Religion+of+Islam&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.islamreligion.com%2Farticles%2F10302%2Fsigns-of-prophethood-in-noble-life-of-prophet-muhammad-part-1%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li>Gibb, Hamilton A.R. and Kramers, J.H. (1965) Shorter Encyclopedia of Islam. Ithaca:Cornell University Press. pp. 191–98</li>
<li><cite class="citation book">Maalouf, Tony. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.ch/books?id=A0BdsFRX55cC&amp;pg=PA44&amp;dq=#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false"><i>Arabs in the Shadow of Israel: The Unfolding of God's Prophetic Plan for Ishmael's Line</i></a>. Kregel Academic. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780825493638" title="Special:BookSources/9780825493638">9780825493638</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Arabs+in+the+Shadow+of+Israel%3A+The+Unfolding+of+God%27s+Prophetic+Plan+for+Ishmael%27s+Line&amp;rft.pub=Kregel+Academic&amp;rft.isbn=9780825493638&amp;rft.aulast=Maalouf&amp;rft.aufirst=Tony&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.ch%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA0BdsFRX55cC%26pg%3DPA44%26dq%3D%23v%3Donepage%26q%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li>
<li><cite class="citation book">Urbain, Olivier (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.ch/books?id=oMLkUmraBCAC&amp;pg=PA208&amp;dq="><i>Music and Conflict Transformation: Harmonies and Dissonances in Geopolitics</i></a>. I.B.Tauris. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9781845115289" title="Special:BookSources/9781845115289">9781845115289</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Music+and+Conflict+Transformation%3A+Harmonies+and+Dissonances+in+Geopolitics&amp;rft.pub=I.B.Tauris&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=9781845115289&amp;rft.aulast=Urbain&amp;rft.aufirst=Olivier&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.ch%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DoMLkUmraBCAC%26pg%3DPA208%26dq%3D&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></li></ul>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-73"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-73">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Delitzsche (1912). <i>Assyriesche Lesestuche</i>. <li id="cite_note-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-75">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Winnet (1970). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=uEFjAAAAMAAJ&amp;dq=qedar#search_anchor"><i>Ancient Records from North Arabia</i></a>. pp.&#160;51, 52. <a href="/wiki/OCLC" title="OCLC">OCLC</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/79767">79767</a>. <q>king of kedar (Qedarites) is named alternatively as king of Ishmaelites and king of Arabs in Assyrian Inscriptions</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ancient+Records+from+North+Arabia&amp;rft.pages=51%2C+52&amp;rft.date=1970&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F79767&amp;rft.au=Winnet&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DuEFjAAAAMAAJ%26dq%3Dqedar%23search_anchor&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-76">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Stetkevychc (2000). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=OVXC72Td6CsC&amp;pg=PA76"><i>Muhammad and the Golden Bough</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-107">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bowman, Alan; Garnsey, Peter; Cameron, Averil (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=MNSyT_PuYVMC&amp;pg=PA508&amp;dq=Abgar+arab#v=snippet&amp;q=%22arab%20principality%20of%20edessa%22&amp;f=false"><i>The Cambridge Ancient History: Volume 12, The Crisis of Empire, AD 193-337</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-108">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Bowman, Alan; Garnsey, Peter; Cameron, Averil (2005). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=MNSyT_PuYVMC&amp;pg=PA500&amp;lpg=PA500&amp;dq=Hatran+arabs#v=onepage&amp;q=Hatran%20arabs&amp;f=false"><i>The Cambridge Ancient History: Volume 12, The Crisis of Empire, AD 193-337</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-109">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=XjxyBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA13&amp;lpg=PA13&amp;dq=arabs+ruled+the+fertile+crescent+as+vassals+of+persians+and+romans#v=onepage&amp;q=arabs%20ruled%20the%20fertile%20crescent%20as%20vassals%20of%20persians%20and%20romans&amp;f=false">https://books.google.com/?id=XjxyBgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA13&amp;lpg=PA13&amp;dq=arabs+ruled+the+fertile+crescent+as+vassals+of+persians+and+romans#v=onepage&amp;q=arabs%20ruled%20the%20fertile%20crescent%20as%20vassals%20of%20persians%20and%20romans&amp;f=false</a>. <q>The Fertile Crescent, on the edges of northern Arabia, formed part of the frontier between the two rival empires of the day, the Sasanian (Persian) and the Byzantine (Eastern Roman). Each of which had a client or vassal state lying between itself and its rival.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2F%3Fid%3DXjxyBgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA13%26lpg%3DPA13%26dq%3Darabs%2Bruled%2Bthe%2Bfertile%2Bcrescent%2Bas%2Bvassals%2Bof%2Bpersians%2Band%2Bromans%23v%3Donepage%26q%3Darabs%2520ruled%2520the%2520fertile%2520crescent%2520as%2520vassals%2520of%2520persians%2520and%2520romans%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span> <span class="cs1-visible-error error citation-comment">Missing or empty <code class="cs1-code">&#124;title=</code> (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#citation_missing_title" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-167"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-167">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.media-citizenship.eu/images/stories/pdf/Amsterdam_national_focus_group_report.pdf">"Dutch media perceived as much more biased than Arabic media – Media &amp; Citizenship Report conducted by University of Utrecht"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>, <i>Utrecht University</i>, 10 September 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 November</span> 2010</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Utrecht+University&amp;rft.atitle=Dutch+media+perceived+as+much+more+biased+than+Arabic+media+%E2%80%93+Media+%26+Citizenship+Report+conducted+by+University+of+Utrecht&amp;rft.date=2010-09-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.media-citizenship.eu%2Fimages%2Fstories%2Fpdf%2FAmsterdam_national_focus_group_report.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AArabs" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r861714446"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template"><span style="white-space: nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot"><span title="&#160;Dead link since July 2017">permanent dead link</span></a></i>&#93;</span></sup></span>

<li id="cite_note-346"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-346">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.muslimheritage.com/article/rediscovering-arabic-science">"Rediscovering Arabic Science | Muslim Heritage"</a>. <i>Muslimheritage.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-401"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-401">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Regueiro;  et al. <li id="cite_note-411"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-411">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Capelli, C.; Redhead, N.; Romano, V.; Cali, F.; Lefranc, G.; Delague, V.; Megarbane, A.; Felice, A. <li id="cite_note-423"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-423">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Ollier, W; Doyle, P; Alonso, A; Awad, J; Williams, E; Gill, D; Welch, S; Klouda, P; Bacchus, R; Festenstein, H (February 1985). <li id="cite_note-Coffman-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Coffman_431-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">E. <li id="cite_note-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-432">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAbu_Amero_et_al.2009">Abu Amero et al. (2009)</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-Semino2004-433"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Semino2004_433-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Semino, O; Magri, C; Benuzzi, G; Lin, AA; Al-Zahery, N; Battaglia, V; MacCioni, L; Triantaphyllidis, C;  et al. (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1181965">"Origin, diffusion, and differentiation of Y-chromosome haplogroups E and J: inferences on the neolithization of Europe and later migratory events in the Mediterranean area"</a>. <i>American Journal of Human Genetics</i>. <b>74</b> (5): 1023–34. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1086%2F386295">10.1086/386295</a>. <a href="/wiki/PubMed_Central" title="PubMed <li id="cite_note-Elsevier_Inc-443"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Elsevier_Inc_443-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arabs&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Further reading">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="People_and_things_in_the_Quran" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist collapsible collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Characters_and_names_in_the_Quran" title="Template:Characters and names in the Quran"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Characters_and_names_in_the_Quran" title="Template talk:Characters and names in the Quran"><abbr title="Discuss this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Characters_and_names_in_the_Quran&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="People_and_things_in_the_Quran" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">People and things in the Quran</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks collapsible expanded navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2"><div id="Characters" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/List_of_characters_and_names_mentioned_in_the_Quran" title="List of characters and names mentioned in the Quran">Characters</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Non-humans</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/God_in_Islam" title="God in Islam">Allāh</a> ("The <a href="/wiki/God" title="God">God</a>")
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Names_of_God_in_Islam#List_of_names_and_attributes_of_God_as_found_in_the_Quran" title="Names of God in Islam">Names</a> of <a href="/wiki/Allah" title="Allah">Allah</a> found in the Quran, such as <i>Karīm</i> (Generous)</li></ul></li>
<li>Beings in Paradise
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Ghilman" title="Ghilman">Ghilmān</a></i> or <i>Wildān</i></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Houri" title="Houri">Ḥūr</a></i></li></ul></li></ul>
 </div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Animals</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Related</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Baqara#Overview" title="Al-Baqara">baqarah</a></i> (cow) of Israelites</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Joseph_in_Islam#The_plot_against_Joseph" title="Joseph in Islam">dhi’b</a></i> (wolf) that Jacob feared could attack Joseph</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Fil" title="Al-Fil">fīl</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/War_elephant" title="War elephant">elephant</a>) of the Abyssinians)</li>
<li><i>Ḥimār</i> (Domesticated donkey)</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Solomon_in_Islam#Reign" title="Solomon in Islam">hud-hud</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Hoopoe" title="Hoopoe">hoopoe</a>) of Solomon</li>
<li>The <i>kalb</i> (dog) of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sleepers#Islamic_interpretation" title="Seven Sleepers">sleepers of the cave</a></li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Solomon_in_Islam#Reign" title="Solomon in Islam">namlah</a></i> (female ant) of Solomon</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/Jonah#The_fish" title="Jonah">nūn</a></i> (fish or whale) of Jonah</li>
<li>The <i><a href="/wiki/She-Camel_of_God" title="She-Camel of God">nāqat</a></i> (she-camel) of Saleh</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Non-related</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><i>Dābbat al-Arḍ</i> (<a href="/wiki/Beast_of_the_Earth" title="Beast of the Earth">Beast of the Earth</a>)</li>
<li><i>Ḥimār</i> (<a href="/wiki/Onager" title="Onager">Wild ass</a>)</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Qaswarah" class="mw-redirect" title="Qaswarah">Qaswarah</a></i> ("<a href="/wiki/Asiatic_lion" title="Asiatic lion">Lion</a>", "beast of prey" or "hunter")</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Islamic_view_of_angels" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamic view of angels">Angels</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li>Angels of Hell
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Maalik" title="Maalik">Mālik</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Zabaniyya" title="Zabaniyya">Zabāniyah</a></i></li></ul></li>
<li>Angel of the Trumpet (<a href="/wiki/Israfil" title="Israfil">Isrāfīl</a> or <a href="/wiki/Raphael_(archangel)" title="Raphael (archangel)">Raphael</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gabriel#Islam" title="Gabriel">Jibrīl</a> (Gabriel)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Michael_(archangel)#Islam" title="Michael (archangel)">Mīkāl</a> (Michael)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Azrael#In_Islam" title="Azrael">‘Izrā’īl Malakul-Mawt</a> (Azrael, Angel of Death)</li>
<li>Riḍwān</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Munkar" class="mw-redirect" title="Munkar">Munkar</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nakir" class="mw-redirect" title="Nakir">Nakir</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Harut_and_Marut" title="Harut and Marut">Harut and Marut</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Current Ummah of Islam (Ummah of Muhammad)</a>
<ul><li><i>Aṣḥāb Muḥammad</i> (<a href="/wiki/Sahabah" title="Sahabah">Companions of Muhammad</a>)

<li><a href="/wiki/Muhajirun" title="Muhajirun">Muhajirun</a> (Emigrants from Mecca to Medina)</li></ul></li></ul></li>
<li>People of <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Locations</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Mentioned</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Holy_Land_(Abrahamic)" class="mw-redirect" title="Holy Land (Abrahamic)">Al-Arḍ Al-Muqaddasah</a></i> ("The Holy Land")
<ul><li>'Blessed' Land</li></ul></li>
<li>In the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> (excluding Madyan)
<ul><li><i><a href="/wiki/Hud_(prophet)#Historical_context" title="Hud (prophet)">Al-Aḥqāf</a></i> ("The Sandy Plains," or "the Wind-curved Sand-hills")

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Jahannam" title="Jahannam">Jahannam</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Hell" title="Hell">Hell</a>)</li>

<ul><li><i>Al-Wādil-Ayman</i> (The valley on the 'righthand' side of the Valley of Tuwa and <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Mount_Sinai" title="Biblical Mount Sinai">Mount Sinai</a>)</li></ul></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Celestial bodies</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"><i>Maṣābīḥ</i> (literally 'lamps'):
<ul><li><i>Al-Qamar</i> (The Moon)</li>
<li><i>Kawākib</i> (Planets)
<ul><li><i>Al-Arḍ</i> (The Earth)</li></ul></li>
<li><i>Nujūm</i> (Stars)
<ul><li><i>Ash-Shams</i> (The Sun)</li></ul></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Liquids</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<li><i>Mā’</i> (Water or fluid)
<ul><li><i>Nahr</i> (River)</li>
<li><i>Yamm</i> (River or sea)</li></ul></li>
<li><i>Sharāb</i> (Drink)</li>
</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Events, incidents,<br />occasions or times</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li>Incident of Ifk</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Laylat_al-Qadr" title="Laylat al-Qadr">Laylat al-Qadr</a></i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mubahala" class="mw-redirect" title="Mubahala">Mubahalah</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Sayl_al-%E2%80%98Arim" class="mw-redirect" title="Sayl al-‘Arim">Sayl al-‘Arim</a></i> (Flood of the Great Dam of <a href="/wiki/Marib" class="mw-redirect" title="Marib">Marib</a> in Sheba)</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Farewell_Pilgrimage" title="Farewell Pilgrimage">Farewell Pilgrimage</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Hudaybiyyah" title="Treaty of Hudaybiyyah">Treaty of Hudaybiyyah</a></li></ul>
</div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th id="Battles_ormilitary_expeditions" scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Battles or<br />military expeditions</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Trench" title="Battle of the Trench">Battle of <i>al-Aḥzāb</i></a> ("the Confederates")</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Badr" title="Battle of Badr">Battle of Badr</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hunayn" title="Battle of Hunayn">Battle of Hunayn</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Khaybar" title="Battle of Khaybar">Battle of Khaybar</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tabouk" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Tabouk">Battle of Tabouk</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Uhud" title="Battle of Uhud">Battle of Uhud</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Mecca" title="Conquest of Mecca">Conquest of Mecca</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
 </div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Days</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Jumu%27ah" title="Jumu&#39;ah">Jumu‘ah</a></i> (The Friday)</li>
<li><i>As-<a href="/wiki/Sabbath#Islam" title="Sabbath">Sabt</a></i> (The Sabbath or Saturday)</li>
<li>Days of battles</li>
<li>Days of Hajj</li>

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
 </div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Months of the<br /><a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Islamic calendar</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li>Four holy months</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramaḍān</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
</div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Pilgrimages</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Hajj" title="Hajj">Ḥajj</a></i> (literally "The Pilgrimage", the Greater Pilgrimage)</li>
<li><i>Al-‘<a href="/wiki/Umrah" title="Umrah">Umrah</a></i> (The Lesser Pilgrimage)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>	
</div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Times for Prayer<br />or Remembrance</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">Times for <i><a href="/wiki/Dua" title="Dua">Duʿāʾ</a></i> ('<a href="/wiki/Invocation" title="Invocation">Invocation</a>'), <i><a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">Ṣalāh</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dhikr" title="Dhikr">Dhikr</a></i> ('Remembrance', including <i><a href="/wiki/Alhamdulillah" title="Alhamdulillah">Taḥmīd</a></i> ('Praising'), <i><a href="/wiki/Takbir" title="Takbir">Takbīr</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Tasbih" title="Tasbih">Tasbīḥ</a></i>):
<ul><li><i>Al-‘Ashiyy</i> (The Afternoon or the Night)</li>
<li><i>Al-Ghuduww</i> ("The Mornings")
<ul><li><i>Al-Bukrah</i> ("The Morning")</li>
<li><i>Aṣ-Ṣabāḥ</i> ("The Morning")</li></ul></li>
<li><i>Al-Layl</i> ("The Night")
<ul><li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Isha_prayer" title="Isha prayer">‘Ishā’</a></i> ("The Late-Night")</li></ul></li>
<li><i>Aẓ-<a href="/wiki/Zuhr_prayer" title="Zuhr prayer">Ẓuhr</a></i> ("The Noon")</li>
<li><i>Dulūk ash-Shams</i> ("Decline of the Sun")
<ul><li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Maghrib_prayer" title="Maghrib prayer">Masā’</a></i> ("The Evening")</li>
<li><i>Qabl al-<a href="/wiki/Maghrib_prayer" title="Maghrib prayer">Ghurūb</a></i> ("Before the Setting (of the Sun)")
<ul><li><i>Al-Aṣīl</i> ("The Afternoon")</li>
<li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Asr_prayer" title="Asr prayer">Aṣr</a></i> ("The Afternoon")</li></ul></li></ul></li>
<li><i>Qabl ṭulū‘ ash-Shams</i> ("Before the rising of the Sun")
<ul><li><i>Al-<a href="/wiki/Fajr_prayer" title="Fajr prayer">Fajr</a></i> ("The Dawn")</li></ul></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
 </div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Implied</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Event_of_Ghadir_Khumm" class="mw-redirect" title="Event of Ghadir Khumm">Event of Ghadir Khumm</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Laylat_al-Mabit" title="Laylat al-Mabit">Laylat al-Mabit</a></i></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/The_first_pilgrimage" title="The first pilgrimage">The first pilgrimage</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div><b>Note:</b> The names are sorted alphabetically. Standard form: Islamic name / Biblical name (title or relationship)</div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
